1.verse: These are the earliest generations of mankind: Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.*

2.verse: These are the earliest generations of mankind: Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.*

3.verse: These are the earliest generations of mankind: Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.*

4.verse: These are the earliest generations of mankind: Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.*

5.verse: The sons of Japheth were: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah. The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Canaan, and Put. The sons of Cush were: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

6.verse: The sons of Japheth were: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah. The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Canaan, and Put. The sons of Cush were: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

7.verse: The sons of Japheth were: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah. The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Canaan, and Put. The sons of Cush were: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

8.verse: The sons of Japheth were: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah. The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Canaan, and Put. The sons of Cush were: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

9.verse: The sons of Japheth were: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. The sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah. The sons of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. The sons of Ham: Cush, Mizraim, Canaan, and Put. The sons of Cush were: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.

10.verse: Another of the sons of Cush was Nimrod, who became a great hero.

11.verse: The clans named after the sons of Mizraim were: the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim, the Pathrusim, the Caphtorim, and the Casluhim (the ancestors of the Philistines).

12.verse: The clans named after the sons of Mizraim were: the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim, the Pathrusim, the Caphtorim, and the Casluhim (the ancestors of the Philistines).

13.verse: Among Canaan’s sons were: Sidon (his firstborn) and Heth. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites, Hivites, Arkites, Sinites, Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.

14.verse: Among Canaan’s sons were: Sidon (his firstborn) and Heth. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites, Hivites, Arkites, Sinites, Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.

15.verse: Among Canaan’s sons were: Sidon (his firstborn) and Heth. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites, Hivites, Arkites, Sinites, Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.

16.verse: Among Canaan’s sons were: Sidon (his firstborn) and Heth. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites, Hivites, Arkites, Sinites, Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.

17.verse: The sons of Shem: Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.

18.verse: Arpachshad’s son was Shelah, and Shelah’s son was Eber.

19.verse: Eber had two sons: Peleg (which means “Divided,” for it was during his lifetime that the people of the earth were divided into different language groups) and Joktan.

20.verse: The sons of Joktan: Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah, Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah, Ebal, Abimael, Sheba, Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab.

21.verse: The sons of Joktan: Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah, Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah, Ebal, Abimael, Sheba, Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab.

22.verse: The sons of Joktan: Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah, Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah, Ebal, Abimael, Sheba, Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab.

23.verse: The sons of Joktan: Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah, Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah, Ebal, Abimael, Sheba, Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab.

24.verse: So the son of Shem was Arpachshad, the son of Arpachshad was Shelah, the son of Shelah was Eber, the son of Eber was Peleg, the son of Peleg was Reu, the son of Reu was Serug, the son of Serug was Nahor, the son of Nahor was Terah, the son of Terah was Abram (later known as Abraham).

25.verse: So the son of Shem was Arpachshad, the son of Arpachshad was Shelah, the son of Shelah was Eber, the son of Eber was Peleg, the son of Peleg was Reu, the son of Reu was Serug, the son of Serug was Nahor, the son of Nahor was Terah, the son of Terah was Abram (later known as Abraham).

26.verse: So the son of Shem was Arpachshad, the son of Arpachshad was Shelah, the son of Shelah was Eber, the son of Eber was Peleg, the son of Peleg was Reu, the son of Reu was Serug, the son of Serug was Nahor, the son of Nahor was Terah, the son of Terah was Abram (later known as Abraham).

27.verse: So the son of Shem was Arpachshad, the son of Arpachshad was Shelah, the son of Shelah was Eber, the son of Eber was Peleg, the son of Peleg was Reu, the son of Reu was Serug, the son of Serug was Nahor, the son of Nahor was Terah, the son of Terah was Abram (later known as Abraham).

28.verse: Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael. The sons of Ishmael: Nebaioth (the oldest), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

29.verse: Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael. The sons of Ishmael: Nebaioth (the oldest), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

30.verse: Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael. The sons of Ishmael: Nebaioth (the oldest), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

31.verse: Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael. The sons of Ishmael: Nebaioth (the oldest), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

32.verse: Abraham also had sons by his concubine Keturah: Zimram, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan’s sons were Sheba and Dedan.

33.verse: The sons of Midian: Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. These were the descendants of Abraham by his concubine Keturah.

34.verse: Abraham’s son Isaac had two sons, Esau and Israel.

35.verse: The sons of Esau: Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.

36.verse: The sons of Eliphaz: Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.

37.verse: The sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.

38.verse: The sons of Esau also included Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan; and Esau’s daughter was named Timna. Lotan’s sons: Hori and Homam.

39.verse: The sons of Esau also included Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan; and Esau’s daughter was named Timna. Lotan’s sons: Hori and Homam.

40.verse: The sons of Shobal: Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. Zibeon’s sons were Aiah and Anah.

41.verse: Anah’s son was Dishon. The sons of Dishon: Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.

42.verse: The sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan. Dishan’s sons were Uz and Aran.

43.verse: Here is a list of the names of the kings of Edom who reigned before the kingdom of Israel began: Bela (the son of Beor), who lived in the city of Dinhabah.

44.verse: When Bela died, Jobab the son of Zerah from Bozrah became the new king.

45.verse: When Jobab died, Husham from the country of the Temanites became the king.

46.verse: When Husham died, Hadad the son of Bedad—the one who destroyed the army of Midian in the fields of Moab—became king and ruled from the city of Avith.

47.verse: When Hadad died, Samlah from the city of Masrekah came to the throne.

48.verse: When Samlah died, Shaul from the river town of Rehoboth became the new king.

49.verse: When Shaul died, Baal-hanan the son of Achbor became king.

50.verse: When Baal-hanan died, Hadad became king and ruled from the city of Pai (his wife was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Mezahab).

51.verse: At the time of Hadad’s death, the kings of Edom were: Chief Timna, Chief Aliah, Chief Jetheth, Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon, Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar, Chief Magdiel, Chief Iram.

52.verse: At the time of Hadad’s death, the kings of Edom were: Chief Timna, Chief Aliah, Chief Jetheth, Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon, Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar, Chief Magdiel, Chief Iram.

53.verse: At the time of Hadad’s death, the kings of Edom were: Chief Timna, Chief Aliah, Chief Jetheth, Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon, Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar, Chief Magdiel, Chief Iram.

54.verse: At the time of Hadad’s death, the kings of Edom were: Chief Timna, Chief Aliah, Chief Jetheth, Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon, Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar, Chief Magdiel, Chief Iram.

1.verse: The sons of Israel were: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, Asher.

2.verse: The sons of Israel were: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, Asher.

3.verse: Judah had three sons by Bathshua, a girl from Canaan: Er, Onan, and Shelah. But the oldest son, Er, was so wicked that the Lord killed him.

4.verse: Then Er’s widow, Tamar, and her father-in-law, Judah, became the parents of twin sons, Perez and Zerah. So Judah had five sons.

5.verse: The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.

6.verse: The sons of Zerah were: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara.

7.verse: (Achan, the son of Carmi, was the man who robbed God and was such a troublemaker for his nation.)

8.verse: Ethan’s son was Azariah.

9.verse: The sons of Hezron were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.

10.verse: Ram was the father of Amminadab, and Amminadab was the father of Nahshon, a leader of Israel.

11.verse: Nahshon was the father of Salma, and Salma was the father of Boaz.

12.verse: Boaz was the father of Obed, and Obed was the father of Jesse.

13.verse: Jesse’s first son was Eliab, his second was Abinadab, his third was Shimea,

14.verse: his fourth was Nethanel, his fifth was Raddai,

15.verse: his sixth was Ozem, and his seventh was David.

16.verse: He also had two girls (by the same wife) named Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah’s sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.

17.verse: Abigail, whose husband was Jether from the land of Ishmael, had a son named Amasa.

18.verse: Caleb (the son of Hezron) had two wives, Azubah and Jerioth. These are the children of Azubah: Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.

19.verse: After Azubah’s death, Caleb married Ephrath, who presented him with a son, Hur.

20.verse: Hur’s son was Uri, and Uri’s son was Bezalel.

21.verse: Hezron married Machir’s daughter at the age of sixty, and she presented him with a son, Segub. (Machir was also the father of Gilead.)

22.verse: Segub was the father of Jair, who ruled twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead.

23.verse: But Geshur and Aram wrested these cities from him and also took Kenath and its sixty surrounding villages.

24.verse: Soon after his father Hezron’s death, Caleb married Ephrathah, his father’s widow, and she gave birth to Ashhur, the father of Tekoa.

25.verse: These are the sons of Jerahmeel (the oldest son of Hezron): Ram (the oldest), Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.

26.verse: Jerahmeel’s second wife Atarah was the mother of Onam.

27.verse: The sons of Ram: Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.

28.verse: Onam’s sons were Shammai and Jada. Shammai’s sons were Nadab and Abishur.

29.verse: The sons of Abishur and his wife Abihail were Ahban and Molid.

30.verse: Nadab’s sons were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without children,

31.verse: but Appaim had a son named Ishi; Ishi’s son was Sheshan; and Sheshan’s son was Ahlai.

32.verse: Shammai’s brother Jada had two sons, Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without children,

33.verse: but Jonathan had two sons named Peleth and Zaza.

34.verse: Sheshan had no sons, although he had several daughters. He gave one of his daughters to be the wife of Jarha, his Egyptian servant. And they had a son whom they named Attai.

35.verse: Sheshan had no sons, although he had several daughters. He gave one of his daughters to be the wife of Jarha, his Egyptian servant. And they had a son whom they named Attai.

36.verse: Attai’s son was Nathan; Nathan’s son was Zabad;

37.verse: Zabad’s son was Ephlal; Ephlal’s son was Obed;

38.verse: Obed’s son was Jehu; Jehu’s son was Azariah;

39.verse: Azariah’s son was Helez; Helez’s son was Eleasah;

40.verse: Eleasah’s son was Sismai; Sismai’s son was Shallum;

41.verse: Shallum’s son was Jekamiah; Jekamiah’s son was Elishama.

42.verse: The oldest son of Caleb (Jerahmeel’s brother) was Mesha; he was the father of Ziph, who was father of Mareshah, who was the father of Hebron.

43.verse: The sons of Hebron: Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.

44.verse: Shema was the father of Raham, who was the father of Jorkeam. Rekem was the father of Shammai.

45.verse: Shammai’s son was Maon, the father of Bethzur.

46.verse: Caleb’s concubine Ephah bore him Haran, Moza, and Gazez; Haran had a son named Gazez.

47.verse: The sons of Jahdai: Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.

48.verse: Another of Caleb’s concubines, Maacah, bore him Sheber, Tirhanah, Shaaph (the father of Madmannah), and Sheva (the father of Machbenah and of Gibea). Caleb also had a daughter, whose name was Achsah.

49.verse: Another of Caleb’s concubines, Maacah, bore him Sheber, Tirhanah, Shaaph (the father of Madmannah), and Sheva (the father of Machbenah and of Gibea). Caleb also had a daughter, whose name was Achsah.

50.verse: The sons of Hur (who was the oldest son of Caleb and Ephrathah) were Shobal (the father of Kiriath-jearim),

51.verse: Salma (the father of Bethlehem), and Hareph (the father of Beth-gader).

52.verse: Shobal’s sons included Kiriath-jearim and Haroeh, the ancestor of half of the Menuhoth tribe.

53.verse: The families of Kiriath-jearim were the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites (from whom descended the Zorathites and Eshtaolites).

54.verse: The descendants of Salma were his son Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atrothbeth-joab, half the Manahathites, and the Zorites;

55.verse: they also included the families of the writers living at Jabez—the Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites. All these are Kenites who descended from Hammath, the founder of the family of Rechab.

1.verse: King David’s oldest son was Amnon, who was born to his wife, Ahinoam of Jezreel. The second was Daniel, whose mother was Abigail from Carmel.

2.verse: The third was Absalom, the son of his wife Maacah, who was the daughter of King Talmai of Geshur. The fourth was Adonijah, the son of Haggith.

3.verse: The fifth was Shephatiah, the son of Abital. The sixth was Ithream, the son of his wife Eglah.

4.verse: These six were born to him in Hebron, where he reigned seven and a half years. Then he moved the capital to Jerusalem, where he reigned another thirty-three years.

5.verse: While he was in Jerusalem, his wife Bathsheba (the daughter of Ammiel) became the mother of his sons Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon.

6.verse: David also had nine other sons: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

7.verse: David also had nine other sons: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

8.verse: David also had nine other sons: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

9.verse: (This list does not include the sons of his concubines.) David also had a daughter Tamar.

10.verse: These are the descendants of King Solomon: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah,* Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah.

11.verse: These are the descendants of King Solomon: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah,* Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah.

12.verse: These are the descendants of King Solomon: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah,* Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah.

13.verse: These are the descendants of King Solomon: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah,* Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah.

14.verse: These are the descendants of King Solomon: Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah,* Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah.

15.verse: The sons of Josiah were: Johanan, Jehoiakim, Zedekiah, Shallum.

16.verse: The sons of Jehoiakim: Jeconiah, Zedekiah.

17.verse: These are the sons who were born to King Jeconiah during the years that he was under house arrest: Shealtiel, Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, Nedabiah.

18.verse: These are the sons who were born to King Jeconiah during the years that he was under house arrest: Shealtiel, Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, Nedabiah.

19.verse: Pedaiah was the father of Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel’s children were: Meshullam, Hananiah, Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, Jushab-hesed, Shelomith (a daughter).

20.verse: Pedaiah was the father of Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel’s children were: Meshullam, Hananiah, Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, Jushab-hesed, Shelomith (a daughter).

21.verse: Hananiah’s sons were Pelatiah and Jeshaiah; Jeshaiah’s son was Rephaiah; Rephaiah’s son was Arnan; Arnan’s son was Obadiah; Obadiah’s son was Shecaniah. Shecaniah’s son was Shemaiah; Shemaiah had six sons, including Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.

22.verse: Hananiah’s sons were Pelatiah and Jeshaiah; Jeshaiah’s son was Rephaiah; Rephaiah’s son was Arnan; Arnan’s son was Obadiah; Obadiah’s son was Shecaniah. Shecaniah’s son was Shemaiah; Shemaiah had six sons, including Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.

23.verse: Neariah had three sons: Elioenai, Hizkiah, Azrikam.

24.verse: Elioenai had seven sons: Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, Anani.

1.verse: These are the sons of Judah: Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, Shobal.

2.verse: Shobal’s son Reaiah was the father of Jahath, the ancestor of Ahumai and Lahad. These were known as the Zorathite clans.

3.verse: The descendants of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, Idbash, Hazzelelponi (his daughter), Penuel (the ancestor of Gedor), Ezer (the ancestor of Hushah), the son of Hur, the oldest son of Ephrathah, who was the father of Bethlehem.

4.verse: The descendants of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, Idbash, Hazzelelponi (his daughter), Penuel (the ancestor of Gedor), Ezer (the ancestor of Hushah), the son of Hur, the oldest son of Ephrathah, who was the father of Bethlehem.

5.verse: Ashhur, the father of Tekoa, had two wives—Helah and Naarah.

6.verse: Naarah bore him Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari;

7.verse: and Helah bore him Zereth, Izhar, and Ethnan.

8.verse: Koz was the father of Anub and Zobebah; he was also the ancestor of the clan named after Aharhel, the son of Harum.

9.verse: Jabez was more distinguished than any of his brothers. His mother named him Jabez because she had such a hard time at his birth (Jabez means “Distress”).

10.verse: He was the one who prayed to the God of Israel, “Oh, that you would wonderfully bless me and help me in my work; please be with me in all that I do, and keep me from all evil and disaster!” And God granted him his request.

11.verse: The descendants of Recah were: Chelub (the brother of Shuhah), whose son was Mahir, the father of Eshton; Eshton was the father of Bethrapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah; Tehinnah was the father of Irnahash.

12.verse: The descendants of Recah were: Chelub (the brother of Shuhah), whose son was Mahir, the father of Eshton; Eshton was the father of Bethrapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah; Tehinnah was the father of Irnahash.

13.verse: The sons of Kenaz were Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel’s sons were Hathath and Meonothai;

14.verse: Meonothai was the father of Ophrah; Seraiah was the father of Joab, the ancestor of the inhabitants of Craftsman Valley (called that because many craftsmen lived there).

15.verse: The sons of Caleb (the son of Jephunneh): Iru, Elah, Naam. The sons of Elah included Kenaz.

16.verse: Jehallelel’s sons were: Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, Asarel.

17.verse: Ezrah’s sons were: Jether, Mered, Epher, Jalon. Mered married Bithiah, an Egyptian princess. She was the mother of Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah—an ancestor of Eshtemoa.

18.verse: Eshtemoa’s wife was a Jewess; she was the mother of Jered, Heber, and Jekuthiel, who were, respectively, the ancestors of the Gedorites, Socoites, and Zanoahites.

19.verse: Hodiah’s wife was the sister of Naham. One of her sons was the father of Keilah the Garmite, and another was the father of Eshtemoa the Maacathite.

20.verse: The sons of Shimon: Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, Tilon. The sons of Ishi: Zoheth, Ben-zoheth.

21.verse: The sons of Shelah (the son of Judah): Er (the father of Lecah), Laadah (the father of Mareshah), The families of the linen workers who worked at Beth-ashbea, Jokim, The clans of Cozeba, Joash, Saraph (who was a ruler in Moab before he returned to Lehem). These names all come from very ancient records.

22.verse: The sons of Shelah (the son of Judah): Er (the father of Lecah), Laadah (the father of Mareshah), The families of the linen workers who worked at Beth-ashbea, Jokim, The clans of Cozeba, Joash, Saraph (who was a ruler in Moab before he returned to Lehem). These names all come from very ancient records.

23.verse: These clans were noted for their pottery, gardening, and planting; they all worked for the king.

24.verse: The sons of Simeon: Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, Shaul.

25.verse: Shaul’s son was Shallum, his grandson was Mibsam, and his great-grandson was Mishma.

26.verse: Mishma’s sons included Hammuel (the father of Zaccur and grandfather of Shimei).

27.verse: Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters, but none of his brothers had large families—they all had fewer children than was normal in Judah.

28.verse: They lived at Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,

31.verse: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These cities were under their control until the time of David.

32.verse: Their descendants also lived in or near Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan; some were as far away as Baal. (These facts are recorded in their genealogies.)

33.verse: Their descendants also lived in or near Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan; some were as far away as Baal. (These facts are recorded in their genealogies.)

34.verse: These are the names of some of the princes of wealthy clans who traveled to the east side of Gedor Valley in search of pasture for their flocks: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah, Joel, Jehu, Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, Ziza (the son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah).

40.verse: They found good pastures, and everything was quiet and peaceful; but the land belonged to the descendants of Ham. So during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah these princes invaded the land and struck down the tents and houses of the descendants of Ham; they killed the inhabitants of the land and took possession of it for themselves.

41.verse: They found good pastures, and everything was quiet and peaceful; but the land belonged to the descendants of Ham. So during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah these princes invaded the land and struck down the tents and houses of the descendants of Ham; they killed the inhabitants of the land and took possession of it for themselves.

42.verse: Later, five hundred of these invaders from the tribe of Simeon went to Mount Seir. (Their leaders were Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel—all sons of Ishi.)

43.verse: There they destroyed the few surviving members of the tribe of Amalek. And they have lived there ever since.

1.verse: The oldest son of Israel was Reuben, but since he dishonored his father by sleeping with one of his father’s wives, his birthright was given to his half brother, Joseph. So the official genealogy doesn’t name Reuben as the oldest son.

2.verse: Although Joseph received the birthright, yet Judah was a powerful and influential tribe in Israel, and from Judah came a prince.

3.verse: The sons of Reuben, Israel’s son, were: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, Carmi.

4.verse: Joel’s descendants were his son Shemaiah, his grandson Gog, and his great-grandson Shimei.

5.verse: Shimei’s son was Micah; his grandson was Reaiah; and his great-grandson was Baal.

6.verse: Baal’s son was Beerah. He was a prince of the tribe of Reuben and was taken into captivity by King Tilgath-pilneser of Assyria.

7.verse: His relatives became heads of clans and were included in the official genealogy: Jeiel, Zechariah, Bela (the son of Azaz, grandson of Shema, and great-grandson of Joel). These Reubenites lived in Aroer and as far distant as Mount Nebo and Baal-meon.

8.verse: His relatives became heads of clans and were included in the official genealogy: Jeiel, Zechariah, Bela (the son of Azaz, grandson of Shema, and great-grandson of Joel). These Reubenites lived in Aroer and as far distant as Mount Nebo and Baal-meon.

9.verse: Joel was a cattleman, and he pastured his animals eastward to the edge of the desert and to the Euphrates River, for there were many cattle in the land of Gilead.

10.verse: During the reign of King Saul, the men of Reuben defeated the Hagrites in war and moved into their tents on the eastern edge of Gilead.

11.verse: Across from them, in the land of Bashan, lived the descendants of Gad, who were spread as far as Salecah.

12.verse: Joel was the greatest and was followed by Shapham, also Janai and Shaphat.

13.verse: Their relatives, the heads of the seven clans, were Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.

14.verse: The descendants of Buz, in the order of their generations, were: Jahdo, Jeshishai, Michael, Gilead, Jaroah, Huri, Abihail.

15.verse: Ahi, the son of Abdiel and grandson of Guni, was the leader of the clan.

16.verse: The clan lived in and around Gilead (in the land of Bashan) and throughout the entire pasture country of Sharon.

17.verse: All were included in the official genealogy at the time of King Jotham of Judah and King Jeroboam of Israel.

18.verse: There were 44,760 armed, trained, and brave troops in the army of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.

19.verse: They declared war on the Hagrites, the Jeturites, the Naphishites, and the Nodabites.

20.verse: They cried out to God to help them, and he did, for they trusted in him. So the Hagrites and all their allies were defeated.

21.verse: The booty included 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep, 2,000 donkeys, and 100,000 captives.

22.verse: A great number of the enemy also died in the battle, for God was fighting against them. So the Reubenites lived in the territory of the Hagrites until the time of the exile.

23.verse: The half-tribe of Manasseh spread through the land from Bashan to Baal-hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. They too were very numerous.

24.verse: The chiefs of their clans were the following: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, Jahdiel. Each of these men had a great reputation as a warrior and leader.

25.verse: But they were not true to the God of their fathers; instead they worshiped the idols of the people whom God had destroyed.

26.verse: So God caused King Pul of Assyria (also known as Tilgath-pilneser III) to invade the land and deport the men of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. They took them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the Gozan River, where they remain to this day.

2.verse: Kohath’s sons were: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, Uzziel.

3.verse: Amram’s descendants included: Aaron, Moses, Miriam. Aaron’s sons were: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, Ithamar.

18.verse: The sons of Kohath were: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, Uzziel.

19.verse: The sons of Merari were: Mahli, Mushi. The subclans of the Levites were: In the Gershom clan: Libni, Jahath, Zimmah, Joah, Iddo, Zerah, Jeatherai.

31.verse: King David appointed song leaders and choirs to praise God in the Tabernacle after he had placed the Ark in it.

32.verse: Then, when Solomon built the Temple at Jerusalem, the choirs carried on their work there.

33.verse: These are the names and ancestries of choir leaders: Heman the Cantor was from the clan of Kohath; his genealogy was traced back through: Joel, Samuel, Elkanah III, Jeroham, Eliel, Toah, Zuph, Elkanah II, Mahath, Amasai, Elkanah I, Joel, Azariah, Zephaniah, Tahath, Assir, Ebiasaph, Korah, Izhar, Kohath, Levi, Israel.

48.verse: Their relatives—all the other Levites—were appointed to various other tasks in the Tabernacle.

49.verse: But only Aaron and his descendants were the priests. Their duties included sacrificing burnt offerings and incense, handling all the tasks relating to the inner sanctuary—the Holy of Holies—and the tasks relating to the annual Day of Atonement for Israel. They saw to it that all the details commanded by Moses the servant of God were strictly followed.

50.verse: The descendants of Aaron were: Eleazar, Phinehas, Abishua, Bukki, Uzzi, Zerahiah, Meraioth, Amariah, Ahitub, Zadok, Ahimaaz.

54.verse: This is a record of the cities and land assigned by lot to the descendants of Aaron, all of whom were members of the Kohath clan:

55.verse: Hebron and its surrounding pasturelands in Judah (although the fields and suburbs were given to Caleb the son of Jephunneh),

58.verse: and the following Cities of Refuge with their surrounding pasturelands: Libnah, Jattir, Eshtemoa, Hilen, Debir, Ashan, Beth-shemesh.

59.verse: and the following Cities of Refuge with their surrounding pasturelands: Libnah, Jattir, Eshtemoa, Hilen, Debir, Ashan, Beth-shemesh.

60.verse: Thirteen other cities with surrounding pastures—including Geba, Alemeth, and Anathoth—were given to the priests by the tribe of Benjamin.

61.verse: Lots were then drawn to assign land to the remaining descendants of Kohath, and they received ten cities in the territory of the half-tribe of Manasseh.

62.verse: The subclans of the Gershom clan received by lot thirteen cities in the Bashan area from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Manasseh.

63.verse: The subclans of Merari received by lot twelve cities from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.

64.verse: Cities and pasturelands were also assigned by lot to the Levites (and then renamed) from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.

76.verse: The tribe of Naphtali gave them Kedesh in Galilee, Hammon, and Kiriathaim with pasturelands.

77.verse: The tribe of Zebulun gave Rimmono and Tabor to the Merari clan as Cities of Refuge.

78.verse: And across the Jordan River, opposite Jericho, the tribe of Reuben gave them Bezer (a desert town), Jahzah, Kedemoth, and Mephaath, along with their pasturelands.

79.verse: And across the Jordan River, opposite Jericho, the tribe of Reuben gave them Bezer (a desert town), Jahzah, Kedemoth, and Mephaath, along with their pasturelands.

80.verse: The tribe of Gad gave them Ramoth in Gilead, Mahanaim,

81.verse: Heshbon, and Jazer, each with their surrounding pasturelands.

1.verse: The sons of Issachar: Tola, Puah, Jashub, Shimron.

2.verse: The sons of Tola, each of whom was the head of a subclan: Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, Shemuel. At the time of King David, the total number of men of war from these families was 22,600.

3.verse: Uzzi’s son was Izrahiah among whose five sons were Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah, all chiefs of subclans.

4.verse: Their descendants, at the time of King David, numbered 36,000 troops; for all five of them had several wives and many sons.

5.verse: The total number of men available for military service from all the clans of the tribe of Issachar was 87,000 stouthearted warriors, all included in the official genealogy.

6.verse: The sons of Benjamin were: Bela, Becher, Jediael.

7.verse: The sons of Bela: Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, Iri. These five mighty warriors were chiefs of subclans and were the leaders of 22,034 troops (all of whom were recorded in the official genealogies).

8.verse: The sons of Becher were: Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, Alemeth.

9.verse: At the time of David there were 20,200 mighty warriors among their descendants; and they were led by their clan chiefs.

10.verse: The son of Jediael was Bilhan. The sons of Bilhan were: Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, Ahishahar.

11.verse: They were the chiefs of the subclans of Jediael, and their descendants included 17,200 warriors at the time of King David.

12.verse: The sons of Ir were Shuppim and Huppim. Hushim was one of the sons of Aher.

13.verse: The sons of Naphtali (descendants of Jacob’s wife Bilhah) were: Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, Shallum.

14.verse: The sons of Manasseh, born to his Aramaean concubine, were Asriel and Machir (who became the father of Gilead).

15.verse: It was Machir who found wives for Huppim and Shuppim. Machir’s sister was Maacah. Another descendant was Zelophehad, who had only daughters.*

16.verse: Machir’s wife, also named Maacah, bore him a son whom she named Peresh; his brother’s name was Sheresh, and he had sons named Ulam and Rakem.

17.verse: Ulam’s son was Bedan. So these were the sons of Gilead, the grandsons of Machir, and the great-grandsons of Manasseh.

18.verse: Hammolecheth, Machir’s sister, bore Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.

19.verse: The sons of Shemida were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.

20.verse: The sons of Ephraim: Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eleadah, Tahath, Zabad, Shuthelah, Ezer, Elead. Elead and Ezer attempted to rustle cattle at Gath, but they were killed by the local farmers.

21.verse: The sons of Ephraim: Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eleadah, Tahath, Zabad, Shuthelah, Ezer, Elead. Elead and Ezer attempted to rustle cattle at Gath, but they were killed by the local farmers.

22.verse: Their father Ephraim mourned for them a long time, and his brothers tried to comfort him.

23.verse: Afterwards his wife conceived and bore a son whom he called Beriah (meaning “a tragedy”) because of what had happened.

24.verse: Ephraim’s daughter’s name was Sheerah. She built Lower and Upper Beth-horon and Uzzen-sheerah.

25.verse: This is Ephraim’s line of descent: Rephah, the father of Resheph, the father of Telah, the father of Tahan, the father of Ladan, the father of Ammihud, the father of Elishama, the father of Nun, the father of Joshua.

26.verse: This is Ephraim’s line of descent: Rephah, the father of Resheph, the father of Telah, the father of Tahan, the father of Ladan, the father of Ammihud, the father of Elishama, the father of Nun, the father of Joshua.

27.verse: This is Ephraim’s line of descent: Rephah, the father of Resheph, the father of Telah, the father of Tahan, the father of Ladan, the father of Ammihud, the father of Elishama, the father of Nun, the father of Joshua.

28.verse: They lived in an area bounded on one side by Bethel and its surrounding towns, on the east by Naaran, on the west by Gezer and its villages, and finally by Shechem and its surrounding villages as far as Ayyah and its towns.

29.verse: The tribe of Manasseh, descendants of Joseph the son of Israel, controlled the following cities and their surrounding areas: Beth-shean, Taanach, Megiddo, and Dor.

30.verse: The children of Asher: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, Serah (their sister).

31.verse: The sons of Beriah were: Heber, Malchiel (the father of Birzaith).

32.verse: Heber’s children were: Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, Shua (their sister).

33.verse: Japhlet’s sons were: Pasach, Bimhal, Ashvath.

34.verse: His brother Shomer’s sons were: Rohgah, Jehubbah, Aram.

35.verse: The sons of his brother Hotham were: Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, Amal.

36.verse: The sons of Zophah were: Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah, Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, Beera.

37.verse: The sons of Zophah were: Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah, Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, Beera.

38.verse: The sons of Ithran were: Jephunneh, Pispa, Ara.

39.verse: The sons of Ulla were: Arah, Hanniel, Rizia.

40.verse: These descendants of Asher were heads of subclans and were all skilled warriors and chiefs. Their descendants in the official genealogy numbered 36,000 men of war.

1.verse: The sons of Benjamin, according to age, were: Bela, the first, Ashbel, the second, Aharah, the third, Nohah, the fourth, Rapha, the fifth.

2.verse: The sons of Benjamin, according to age, were: Bela, the first, Ashbel, the second, Aharah, the third, Nohah, the fourth, Rapha, the fifth.

3.verse: The sons of Bela were: Addar, Gera, Abihud, Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah, Gera, Shephuphan, Huram.

4.verse: The sons of Bela were: Addar, Gera, Abihud, Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah, Gera, Shephuphan, Huram.

5.verse: The sons of Bela were: Addar, Gera, Abihud, Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah, Gera, Shephuphan, Huram.

6.verse: The sons of Ehud, chiefs of the subclans living at Geba, were captured in war and exiled to Manahath. They were: Naaman, Ahijah, Gera (also called Heglam), the father of Uzza and Ahihud.

7.verse: The sons of Ehud, chiefs of the subclans living at Geba, were captured in war and exiled to Manahath. They were: Naaman, Ahijah, Gera (also called Heglam), the father of Uzza and Ahihud.

8.verse: Shaharaim divorced his wives Hushim and Baara, but he had children in the land of Moab by Hodesh, his new wife: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sachia, Mirmah. These sons all became chiefs of subclans.

9.verse: Shaharaim divorced his wives Hushim and Baara, but he had children in the land of Moab by Hodesh, his new wife: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sachia, Mirmah. These sons all became chiefs of subclans.

10.verse: Shaharaim divorced his wives Hushim and Baara, but he had children in the land of Moab by Hodesh, his new wife: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sachia, Mirmah. These sons all became chiefs of subclans.

11.verse: His wife Hushim had borne him Abitub and Elpaal.

12.verse: The sons of Elpaal were: Eber, Misham, Shemed (who built Ono and Lod and their surrounding villages).

13.verse: His other sons were Beriah and Shema, chiefs of subclans living in Aijalon; they chased out the inhabitants of Gath.

14.verse: Elpaal’s sons also included: Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth.

15.verse: The sons of Beriah were: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder, Michael, Ishpah, Joha.

16.verse: The sons of Beriah were: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder, Michael, Ishpah, Joha.

17.verse: The sons of Elpaal also included: Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber, Ishmerai, Izliah, Jobab.

18.verse: The sons of Elpaal also included: Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber, Ishmerai, Izliah, Jobab.

19.verse: The sons of Shimei were: Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi, Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel, Adaiah, Beraiah, Shimrath.

20.verse: The sons of Shimei were: Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi, Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel, Adaiah, Beraiah, Shimrath.

21.verse: The sons of Shimei were: Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi, Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel, Adaiah, Beraiah, Shimrath.

22.verse: The sons of Shashak were: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah, Iphdeiah, Penuel.

23.verse: The sons of Shashak were: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah, Iphdeiah, Penuel.

24.verse: The sons of Shashak were: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah, Iphdeiah, Penuel.

25.verse: The sons of Shashak were: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah, Iphdeiah, Penuel.

26.verse: The sons of Jeroham were: Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah, Jaareshiah, Elijah, Zichri.

27.verse: The sons of Jeroham were: Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah, Jaareshiah, Elijah, Zichri.

28.verse: These were the chiefs of the subclans living at Jerusalem.

29.verse: Jeiel, the father of Gibeon, lived at Gibeon; and his wife’s name was Maacah.

30.verse: His oldest son was named Abdon, followed by: Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zecher, Mikloth who was the father of Shimeah. All of these families lived together near Jerusalem.

31.verse: His oldest son was named Abdon, followed by: Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zecher, Mikloth who was the father of Shimeah. All of these families lived together near Jerusalem.

32.verse: His oldest son was named Abdon, followed by: Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zecher, Mikloth who was the father of Shimeah. All of these families lived together near Jerusalem.

33.verse: Ner was the father of Kish, and Kish was the father of Saul; Saul’s sons included: Jonathan, Malchi-shua, Abinadab, Eshbaal.

34.verse: The son of Jonathan was Mephibosheth; The son of Mephibosheth* was Micah.

35.verse: The sons of Micah: Pithon, Melech, Tarea, Ahaz.

36.verse: Ahaz was the father of Jehoaddah, Jehoaddah was the father of: Alemeth, Azmaveth, Zimri. Zimri’s son was Moza.

37.verse: Moza was the father of Binea, whose sons were: Raphah, Eleasah, Azel.

38.verse: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, Hanan.

39.verse: Azel’s brother Eshek had three sons: Ulam, the first, Jeush, the second, Eliphelet, the third.

40.verse: Ulam’s sons were prominent warriors who were expert marksmen with their bows. These men had 150 sons and grandsons, and they were all from the tribe of Benjamin.

1.verse: The family tree of every person in Israel was carefully recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel. Judah was exiled to Babylon because the people worshiped idols.

2.verse: The first to return and live again in their former cities were families from the tribes of Israel and also the priests, the Levites, and the Temple assistants.

3.verse: Then some families from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh arrived in Jerusalem:

4.verse: One family was that of Uthai (the son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani) of the clan of Perez (son of Judah).

5.verse: The Shilonites were another family to return, including Asaiah (Shilon’s oldest son) and his sons;

6.verse: there were also the sons of Zerah, including Jeuel and his relatives: 690 in all.

7.verse: Among the members of the tribe of Benjamin who returned were these: Sallu (the son of Meshullam, the son of Hodaviah, the son of Hassenuah); Ibneiah (the son of Jeroham); Elah (the son of Uzzi, the son of Michri); Meshullam (the son of Shephatiah, the son of Reuel, the son of Ibnijah).

8.verse: Among the members of the tribe of Benjamin who returned were these: Sallu (the son of Meshullam, the son of Hodaviah, the son of Hassenuah); Ibneiah (the son of Jeroham); Elah (the son of Uzzi, the son of Michri); Meshullam (the son of Shephatiah, the son of Reuel, the son of Ibnijah).

9.verse: These men were all chiefs of subclans. A total of 956 Benjaminites returned.

10.verse: The priests who returned were: Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin, Azariah (the son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub). He was the chief custodian of the Temple.

11.verse: The priests who returned were: Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin, Azariah (the son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub). He was the chief custodian of the Temple.

12.verse: Another of the returning priests was Adaiah (son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah). Another priest was Maasai (son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer).

13.verse: In all, 1,760 priests returned.

14.verse: Among the Levites who returned was Shemaiah (son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, who was a descendant of Merari).

15.verse: Other Levites who returned included: Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah (the son of Mica, who was the son of Zichri, who was the son of Asaph), Obadiah (the son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun), Berechiah (the son of Asa, son of Elkanah, who lived in the area of the Netophathites).

16.verse: Other Levites who returned included: Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah (the son of Mica, who was the son of Zichri, who was the son of Asaph), Obadiah (the son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun), Berechiah (the son of Asa, son of Elkanah, who lived in the area of the Netophathites).

17.verse: The gatekeepers were Shallum (the chief gatekeeper), Akkub, Talmon, and Ahiman—all Levites. They are still responsible for the eastern royal gate.

18.verse: The gatekeepers were Shallum (the chief gatekeeper), Akkub, Talmon, and Ahiman—all Levites. They are still responsible for the eastern royal gate.

19.verse: Shallum’s ancestry went back through Kore and Ebiasaph to Korah. He and his close relatives the Korahites were in charge of the sacrifices and the protection of the sanctuary, just as their ancestors had supervised and guarded the Tabernacle.

20.verse: Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, was the first director of this division in ancient times. And the Lord was with him.

21.verse: At that time Zechariah, the son of Meshelemiah, had been responsible for the protection of the entrance to the Tabernacle.

22.verse: There were 212 doorkeepers in those days. They were chosen from their villages on the basis of their genealogies, and they were appointed by David and Samuel because of their reliability.

23.verse: They and their descendants were in charge of the Lord’s Tabernacle.

24.verse: They were assigned to each of the four sides: east, west, north, and south.

25.verse: And their relatives in the villages were assigned to help them from time to time, for seven days at a time.

26.verse: The four head gatekeepers, all Levites, were in an office of great trust, for they were responsible for the rooms and treasuries in the Tabernacle of God.

27.verse: Because of their important positions, they lived near the Tabernacle, and they opened the gates each morning.

28.verse: Some of them were assigned to care for the various vessels used in the sacrifices and worship; they checked them in and out to avoid loss.

29.verse: Others were responsible for the furniture, the items in the sanctuary, and the supplies such as fine flour, wine, incense, and spices.

30.verse: Other priests prepared the spices and incense.

31.verse: And Mattithiah (a Levite and the oldest son of Shallum the Korahite) was entrusted with making the flat cakes for grain offerings.

32.verse: Some members of the Kohath clan were in charge of the preparation of the special bread each Sabbath.

33.verse: The cantors were all prominent Levites. They lived in Jerusalem at the Temple and were on duty at all hours. They were free from other responsibilities and were selected by their genealogies.

34.verse: The cantors were all prominent Levites. They lived in Jerusalem at the Temple and were on duty at all hours. They were free from other responsibilities and were selected by their genealogies.

35.verse: Jeiel (whose wife was Maacah) lived in Gibeon. He had many sons, including: Gibeon, Abdon (the oldest), Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, Mikloth.

36.verse: Jeiel (whose wife was Maacah) lived in Gibeon. He had many sons, including: Gibeon, Abdon (the oldest), Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, Mikloth.

37.verse: Jeiel (whose wife was Maacah) lived in Gibeon. He had many sons, including: Gibeon, Abdon (the oldest), Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, Mikloth.

38.verse: Mikloth lived with his son Shimeam in Jerusalem near his relatives.

39.verse: Ner was the father of Kish, Kish was the father of Saul, Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malchi-shua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.

40.verse: Jonathan was the father of Mephibosheth; Mephibosheth* was the father of Micah;

41.verse: Micah was the father of Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz;

42.verse: Ahaz was the father of Jarah; Jarah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; Zimri was the father of Moza.

43.verse: Moza was the father of Binea, Rephaiah, Eleasah, and Azel.

44.verse: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, Hanan.

1.verse: The Philistines attacked and defeated the Israeli troops, who turned and fled and were slaughtered on the slopes of Mount Gilboa.

2.verse: They caught up with Saul and his three sons, Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchi-shua, and killed them all.

3.verse: Saul had been hard pressed with heavy fighting all around him, when the Philistine archers shot and wounded him.

4.verse: He cried out to his bodyguard, “Quick, kill me with your sword before these uncircumcised heathen capture and torture me.” But the man was afraid to do it, so Saul took his own sword and fell against its point; and it pierced his body.

5.verse: Then his bodyguard, seeing that Saul was dead, killed himself in the same way.

6.verse: So Saul and his three sons died together; the entire family was wiped out in one day.

7.verse: When the Israelis in the valley below the mountain heard that their troops had been routed and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled. And the Philistines came and lived in them.

8.verse: When the Philistines went back the next day to strip the bodies of the men killed in action and to gather the booty from the battlefield, they found the bodies of Saul and his sons.

9.verse: So they stripped off Saul’s armor and cut off his head; then they displayed them throughout the nation and celebrated the wonderful news before their idols.

10.verse: They fastened his armor to the walls of the Temple of the Gods and nailed his head to the wall of Dagon’s temple.

11.verse: But when the people of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,

12.verse: their heroic warriors went out to the battlefield and brought back his body and the bodies of his three sons. Then they buried them beneath the oak tree at Jabesh and mourned and fasted for seven days.

13.verse: Saul died for his disobedience to the Lord and because he had consulted a medium,

14.verse: and did not ask the Lord for guidance. So the Lord killed him and gave the kingdom to David, the son of Jesse.

1.verse: Then the leaders of Israel went to David at Hebron and told him, “We are your relatives,

2.verse: and even when Saul was king, you were the one who led our armies to battle and brought them safely back again. And the Lord your God has told you, ‘You shall be the shepherd of my people Israel. You shall be their king.’”

3.verse: So David made a contract with them before the Lord, and they anointed him as king of Israel, just as the Lord had told Samuel.

4.verse: Then David and the leaders went to Jerusalem (or Jebus, as it used to be called) where the Jebusites—the original inhabitants of the land—lived.

5.verse: But the people of Jebus refused to let them enter the city. So David captured the fortress of Zion, later called the City of David, and said to his men, “The first man to kill a Jebusite shall be made commander-in-chief!” Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the first, so he became the general of David’s army.

6.verse: But the people of Jebus refused to let them enter the city. So David captured the fortress of Zion, later called the City of David, and said to his men, “The first man to kill a Jebusite shall be made commander-in-chief!” Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the first, so he became the general of David’s army.

7.verse: David lived in the fortress and that is why that area of Jerusalem is called the City of David.

8.verse: He extended the city out around the fortress while Joab rebuilt the rest of Jerusalem.

9.verse: And David became more and more famous and powerful, for the Lord of the heavens was with him.

10.verse: These are the names of some of the bravest of David’s warriors (who also encouraged the leaders of Israel to make David their king, as the Lord had said would happen):

11.verse: Jashobeam (the son of a man from Hachmon) was the leader of The Top Three—the three greatest heroes among David’s men. He once killed 300 men with his spear.

12.verse: The second of The Top Three was Eleazar, the son of Dodo, a member of the subclan of Ahoh.

13.verse: He was with David in the battle against the Philistines at Pasdammim. The Israeli army was in a barley field and had begun to run away,

14.verse: but he held his ground in the middle of the field, and recovered it and slaughtered the Philistines; and the Lord saved them with a great victory.

15.verse: Another time, three of The Thirty went to David while he was hiding in the cave of Adullam. The Philistines were camped in the valley of Rephaim,

16.verse: and David was in the stronghold at the time; an outpost of the Philistines had occupied Bethlehem.

17.verse: David wanted a drink from the Bethlehem well beside the gate, and when he mentioned this to his men,

18.verse: these three broke through to the Philistine camp, drew some water from the well, and brought it back to David. But he refused to drink it! Instead he poured it out as an offering to the Lord and said, “God forbid that I should drink it! It is the very blood of these men who risked their lives to get it.”

19.verse: these three broke through to the Philistine camp, drew some water from the well, and brought it back to David. But he refused to drink it! Instead he poured it out as an offering to the Lord and said, “God forbid that I should drink it! It is the very blood of these men who risked their lives to get it.”

20.verse: Abishai, Joab’s brother, was commander of The Thirty. He had gained his place among The Thirty by killing 300 men at one time with his spear.

21.verse: He was the chief and the most famous of The Thirty, but he was not as great as The Three.

22.verse: Benaiah, whose father was a mighty warrior from Kabzeel, killed the two famous giants from Moab. He also killed a lion in a slippery pit when there was snow on the ground.

23.verse: Once he killed an Egyptian who was seven and a half feet tall, whose spear was as thick as a weaver’s beam. But Benaiah went up to him with only a club in his hand, and pulled the spear away from him and used it to kill him.

24.verse: He was nearly as great as The Three, and he was very famous among The Thirty. David made him captain of his bodyguard.

25.verse: He was nearly as great as The Three, and he was very famous among The Thirty. David made him captain of his bodyguard.

1.verse: These are the names of the famous warriors who joined David at Ziklag while he was hiding from King Saul.

2.verse: All of them were expert archers and slingers, and they could use their left hands as readily as their right! Like King Saul, they were all of the tribe of Benjamin.

3.verse: Their chief was Ahiezer, son of Shemaah from Gibeah. The others were: His brother Joash; Jeziel and Pelet, sons of Azmaveth; Beracah; Jehu from Anathoth; Ishmaiah from Gibeon (a brave warrior rated as high or higher than The Thirty); Jeremiah; Jahaziel; Johanan; Jozabad from Gederah; Eluzai; Jerimoth; Bealiah; Shemariah; Shephatiah from Haruph; Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, Jashobeam—all Korahites; Joelah and Zebadiah (sons of Jeroham from Gedor).

4.verse: Their chief was Ahiezer, son of Shemaah from Gibeah. 8.verse: Great and brave warriors from the tribe of Gad also went to David in the wilderness. They were experts with both shield and spear and were “lion-faced men, swift as deer upon the mountains.” Ezer was the chief; Obadiah was second in command; Eliab was third in command; Mishmannah was fourth in command; Jeremiah was fifth in command; Attai was sixth in command; Eliel was seventh in command; Johanan was eighth in command; Elzabad was ninth in command; Jeremiah was tenth in command; Machbannai was eleventh in command.

They were experts with both shield and spear and were “lion-faced men, swift as deer upon the mountains.” Ezer was the chief; Obadiah was second in command; Eliab was third in command; Mishmannah was fourth in command; Jeremiah was fifth in command; Attai was sixth in command; Eliel was seventh in command; Johanan was eighth in command; Elzabad was ninth in command; Jeremiah was tenth in command; Machbannai was eleventh in command.

14.verse: These men were army officers; the weakest was worth a hundred normal troops, and the greatest was worth a thousand!

15.verse: They crossed the Jordan River during its seasonal flooding and conquered the lowlands on both the east and west banks.

16.verse: Others came to David from Benjamin and Judah.

17.verse: David went out to meet them and said, “If you have come to help me, we are friends; but if you have come to betray me to my enemies when I am innocent, then may the God of our fathers see and judge you.”

18.verse: Then the Holy Spirit came upon them, and Amasai, a leader of The Thirty, replied, “We are yours, David; We are on your side, son of Jesse. Peace, peace be unto you, And peace to all who aid you; For your God is with you.” So David let them join him, and he made them captains of his army.

19.verse: Some men from Manasseh deserted the Israeli army and joined David just as he was going into battle with the Philistines against King Saul. But as it turned out, the Philistine generals refused to let David and his men go with them. After much discussion they sent them back, for they were afraid that David and his men would imperil them by deserting to King Saul.

20.verse: Here is a list of the men from Manasseh who deserted to David as he was en route to Ziklag: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, Zillethai. Each was a high-ranking officer of Manasseh’s troops.

21.verse: They were brave and able warriors, and they assisted David when he fought against the Amalek raiders at Ziklag.

22.verse: More men joined David almost every day until he had a tremendous army—the army of God.

23.verse: Here is the registry of recruits who joined David at Hebron. They were all anxious to see David become king instead of Saul, just as the Lord had said would happen.

24.verse: From Judah, 6,800 troops armed with shields and spears. From the tribe of Simeon, 7,100 outstanding warriors. From the Levites, 4,600. From the priests—descendants of Aaron—there were 3,700 troops under the command of Zadok, a young man of unusual courage, and Jehoiada. (He and twenty-two members of his family were officers of the fighting priests.) From the tribe of Benjamin, the same tribe Saul was from, there were 3,000. (Most of that tribe retained its allegiance to Saul.) From the tribe of Ephraim, 20,800 mighty warriors, each famous in his respective clan. From the half-tribe of Manasseh, 18,000 were sent for the express purpose of helping David become king. From the tribe of Issachar there were 200 leaders of the tribe with their relatives—all men who understood the temper of the times and knew the best course for Israel to take. From the tribe of Zebulun there were 50,000 trained warriors; they were fully armed and totally loyal to David. From Naphtali there were 1,000 officers and 37,000 troops equipped with shields and spears. From the tribe of Dan there were 28,600 troops, all of them prepared for war. From the tribe of Asher, there were 40,000 trained and ready troops. From the other side of the Jordan River—where the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh lived—there were 120,000 troops equipped with every kind of weapon.

From the half-tribe of Manasseh, 18,000 were sent for the express purpose of helping David become king. From the tribe of Issachar there were 200 leaders of the tribe with their relatives—all men who understood the temper of the times and knew the best course for Israel to take. From the tribe of Zebulun there were 50,000 trained warriors; they were fully armed and totally loyal to David. From Naphtali there were 1,000 officers and 37,000 troops equipped with shields and spears. From the tribe of Dan there were 28,600 troops, all of them prepared for war. From the tribe of Asher, there were 40,000 trained and ready troops. From the other side of the Jordan River—where the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh lived—there were 120,000 troops equipped with every kind of weapon.

From the priests—descendants of Aaron—there were 3,700 troops under the command of Zadok, a young man of unusual courage, and Jehoiada.
