38.verse: All these men came in battle array to Hebron with the single purpose of making David the king of Israel. In fact, all of Israel was ready for this change.

39.verse: They feasted and drank with David for three days, for preparations had been made for their arrival.

40.verse: People from nearby and from as far away as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali brought food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen. Vast supplies of flour, fig cakes, raisins, wine, oil, cattle, and sheep were brought to the celebration, for joy had spread throughout the land.

1.verse: After David had consulted with all of his army officers,

2.verse: he addressed the assembled men of Israel as follows: “Since you think that I should be your king, and since the Lord our God has given his approval, let us send messages to our brothers throughout the land of Israel, including the priests and Levites, inviting them to come and join us.

3.verse: And let us bring back the Ark of our God, for we have been neglecting it ever since Saul became king.”

4.verse: There was unanimous consent, for everyone agreed with him.

5.verse: So David summoned the people of Israel from all across the nation so that they could be present when the Ark of God was brought from Kiriath-jearim.

6.verse: Then David and all Israel went to Baalah (i.e., Kiriath-jearim) in Judah to bring back the Ark of the Lord God enthroned above the Guardian Angels.

7.verse: It was taken from the house of Abinadab on a new cart. Uzza and Ahio drove the oxen.

8.verse: Then David and all the people danced before the Lord with great enthusiasm, accompanied by singing and by zithers, harps, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.

9.verse: But as they arrived at the threshing floor of Chidon, the oxen stumbled and Uzza reached out his hand to steady the Ark.

10.verse: Then the anger of the Lord blazed out against Uzza, and killed him because he had touched the Ark. And so he died there before God.

11.verse: David was angry at the Lord for what he had done to Uzza and he named the place “The Outbreak Against Uzza.” And it is still called that today.

12.verse: Now David was afraid of God and asked, “How shall I ever get the Ark of God home?”

13.verse: Finally he decided to take it to the home of Obed-edom the Gittite instead of bringing it to the City of David.

14.verse: The Ark remained there with the family of Obed-edom for three months, and the Lord blessed him and his family.

1.verse: King Hiram of Tyre sent masons and carpenters to help build David’s palace and he supplied him with much cedar lumber.

2.verse: David now realized why the Lord had made him king and why he had made his kingdom so great; it was for a special reason—to give joy to God’s people!

3.verse: After David moved to Jerusalem, he married additional wives and became the father of many sons and daughters.

4.verse: These are the names of the sons born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, Eliphelet.

5.verse: These are the names of the sons born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, Eliphelet.

6.verse: These are the names of the sons born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, Eliphelet.

7.verse: These are the names of the sons born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, Eliphelet.

8.verse: When the Philistines heard that David was Israel’s new king, they mobilized their forces to capture him. But David learned that they were on the way, so he called together his army.

9.verse: The Philistines were raiding the valley of Rephaim,

10.verse: and David asked the Lord, “If I go out and fight them, will you give me the victory?” And the Lord replied, “Yes, I will.”

11.verse: So he attacked them at Baal-perazim and wiped them out. He exulted, “God has used me to sweep away my enemies like water bursting through a dam!” That is why the place has been known as Baal-perazim ever since (meaning, “The Place of Breaking Through”).

12.verse: After the battle the Israelis picked up many idols left by the Philistines, but David ordered them burned.

13.verse: Later the Philistines raided the valley again,

14.verse: and again David asked God what to do. The Lord replied, “Go around by the mulberry trees and attack from there.

15.verse: When you hear a sound like marching in the tops of the mulberry trees, that is your signal to attack, for God will go before you and destroy the enemy.”

16.verse: So David did as the Lord commanded him; and he cut down the army of the Philistines all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.

17.verse: David’s fame spread everywhere, and the Lord caused all the nations to fear him.

1.verse: David now built several palaces for himself in Jerusalem, and he also built a new Tabernacle to house the Ark of God,

2.verse: and issued these instructions: “When we transfer the Ark to its new home, no one except the Levites may carry it, for God has chosen them for this purpose; they are to minister to him forever.”

3.verse: Then David summoned all Israel to Jerusalem to celebrate the bringing of the Ark into the new Tabernacle.

4.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

5.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

6.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

7.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

8.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

9.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

10.verse: These were the priests and Levites present: 120 from the clan of Kohath; with Uriel as their leader; 220 from the clan of Merari; with Asaiah as their leader; 130 from the clan of Gershom; with Joel as their leader; 200 from the subclan of Elizaphan; with Shemaiah as their leader; 80 from the subclan of Hebron; with Eliel as their leader; 112 from the subclan of Uzziel; with Amminadab as their leader.

11.verse: Then David called for Zadok and Abiathar, the High Priests, and for the Levite leaders: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab.

12.verse: “You are the leaders of the clans of the Levites,” he told them. “Now sanctify yourselves with all your brothers so that you may bring the Ark of Jehovah, the God of Israel, to the place I have prepared for it.

13.verse: The Lord destroyed us before because we handled the matter improperly—you were not carrying it.”

14.verse: So the priests and the Levites underwent the ceremonies of sanctification in preparation for bringing home the Ark of Jehovah, the God of Israel.

15.verse: Then the Levites carried the Ark on their shoulders with its carrying poles, just as the Lord had instructed Moses.

16.verse: King David also ordered the Levite leaders to organize the singers into an orchestra, and they played loudly and joyously upon psaltries, harps, and cymbals.

17.verse: Heman (son of Joel), Asaph (son of Berechiah), and Ethan (son of Kushaiah) from the clan of Merari were the heads of the musicians.

18.verse: The following men were chosen as their assistants: Zechariah, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom and Jeiel, the doorkeepers.

19.verse: Heman, Asaph, and Ethan were chosen to sound the bronze cymbals;

20.verse: and Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah comprised an octet accompanied by harps.

21.verse: Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, Jeiel, and Azaziah were the harpists.

22.verse: The song leader was Chenaniah, the chief of the Levites, who was selected for his skill.

23.verse: Berechiah and Elkanah were guards for the Ark.

24.verse: Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer—all of whom were priests—formed a bugle corps to march at the head of the procession. And Obed-edom and Jehiah guarded the Ark.

25.verse: Then David and the elders of Israel and the high officers of the army went with great joy to the home of Obed-edom to take the Ark to Jerusalem.

26.verse: And because God didn’t destroy the Levites who were carrying the Ark, they sacrificed seven bulls and seven lambs.

27.verse: David, the Levites carrying the Ark, the singers, and Chenaniah the song leader were all dressed in linen robes. David also wore a linen ephod.

28.verse: So the leaders of Israel took the Ark to Jerusalem with shouts of joy, the blowing of horns and trumpets, the crashing of cymbals, and loud playing on the harps and zithers.

29.verse: (But as the Ark arrived in Jerusalem, David’s wife Michal, the daughter of King Saul, felt a deep disgust for David as she watched from the window and saw him dancing like a madman.)

1.verse: So they brought the Ark of God into the special tent that David had prepared for it, and the leaders of Israel sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings before God.

2.verse: At the conclusion of these offerings David blessed the people in the name of the Lord;

3.verse: then he gave every person present (men and women alike) a loaf of bread, some wine, and a cake of raisins.

4.verse: He appointed certain of the Levites to minister before the Ark by giving constant praise and thanks to the Lord God of Israel and by asking for his blessings upon his people. These are the names of those given this assignment:

5.verse: Asaph, the leader of this detail, sounded the cymbals. His associates were Zechariah, Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel; they played the harps and zithers.

6.verse: The priests Benaiah and Jahaziel played their trumpets regularly before the Ark.

7.verse: At that time David began the custom of using choirs in the Tabernacle to sing thanksgiving to the Lord. Asaph was the director of this choral group of priests.

8.verse: “Oh, give thanks to the Lord and pray to him,” they sang. “Tell the peoples of the world About his mighty doings.

9.verse: Sing to him; yes, sing his praises And tell of his marvelous works.

10.verse: Glory in his holy name; Let all rejoice who seek the Lord.

11.verse: Seek the Lord; yes, seek his strength And seek his face untiringly.

12.verse: O descendants of his servant Abraham, O chosen sons of Jacob, Remember his mighty miracles And his marvelous miracles And his authority:

13.verse: O descendants of his servant Abraham, O chosen sons of Jacob, Remember his mighty miracles And his marvelous miracles And his authority:

14.verse: He is the Lord our God! His authority is seen throughout the earth.

15.verse: Remember his covenant forever— The words he commanded To a thousand generations:

16.verse: His agreement with Abraham, And his oath to Isaac,

17.verse: And his confirmation to Jacob. He promised Israel With an everlasting promise:

18.verse: ‘I will give you the land of Canaan As your inheritance.’

19.verse: When Israel was few in number—oh, so few— And merely strangers in the Promised Land;

20.verse: When they wandered from country to country, From one kingdom to another—

21.verse: God didn’t let anyone harm them. Even kings were killed who sought to hurt them.

22.verse: ‘Don’t harm my chosen people,’ he declared. ‘These are my prophets—touch them not.’

23.verse: Sing to the Lord, O Earth, Declare each day that he is the one who saves!

24.verse: Show his glory to the nations! Tell everyone about his miracles.

25.verse: For the Lord is great and should be highly praised; He is to be held in awe above all gods.

26.verse: The other so-called gods are demons, But the Lord made the heavens.

27.verse: Majesty and honor march before him, Strength and gladness walk beside him.

28.verse: O people of all nations of the earth, Ascribe great strength and glory to his name!

29.verse: Yes, ascribe to the Lord The glory due his name! Bring an offering and come before him; Worship the Lord when clothed with holiness!

30.verse: Tremble before him, all the earth! The world stands unmoved.

31.verse: Let the heavens be glad, the earth rejoice; Let all the nations say, ‘It is the Lord who reigns.’

32.verse: Let the vast seas roar, Let the countryside and everything in it rejoice!

33.verse: Let the trees in the woods sing for joy before the Lord, For he comes to judge the earth.

34.verse: Oh, give thanks to the Lord, for he is good; His love and his kindness go on forever.

35.verse: Cry out to him, ‘Oh, save us, God of our salvation; Bring us safely back from among the nations. Then we will thank your holy name, And triumph in your praise.’

36.verse: Blessed be Jehovah, God of Israel, Forever and forevermore.” And all the people shouted “Amen!” and praised the Lord.

37.verse: David arranged for Asaph and his fellow Levites to minister regularly at the Tabernacle, doing each day whatever needed to be done.

38.verse: This group included Obed-edom (the son of Jeduthun), Hosah, and sixty-eight of their colleagues as guards.

39.verse: Meanwhile the old Tabernacle of the Lord on the hill of Gibeon continued to be active. David left Zadok the priest and his fellow priests to minister to the Lord there.

40.verse: They sacrificed burnt offerings to the Lord each morning and evening upon the altar set aside for that purpose, just as the Lord had commanded Israel.

41.verse: David also appointed Heman, Jeduthun, and several others who were chosen by name to give thanks to the Lord for his constant love and mercy.

42.verse: They used their trumpets and cymbals to accompany the singers with loud praises to God. And Jeduthun’s sons were appointed as guards.

43.verse: At last the celebration ended and the people returned to their homes, and David returned to bless his own household.

1.verse: After David had been living in his new palace for some time he said to Nathan the prophet, “Look! I’m living here in a cedar-paneled home while the Ark of the Covenant of God is out there in a tent!”

2.verse: And Nathan replied, “Carry out your plan in every detail, for it is the will of the Lord.”

3.verse: But that same night God said to Nathan,

4.verse: “Go and give my servant David this message: ‘You are not to build my temple!

5.verse: I’ve gone from tent to tent as my home from the time I brought Israel out of Egypt.

6.verse: In all that time I never suggested to any of the leaders of Israel—the shepherds I appointed to care for my people—that they should build me a cedar-lined temple.’

7.verse: “Tell my servant David, ‘The Lord of heaven says to you, I took you from being a shepherd and made you the king of my people.

8.verse: And I have been with you everywhere you’ve gone; I have destroyed your enemies, and I will make your name as great as the greatest of the earth.

9.verse: And I will give a permanent home to my people Israel and will plant them in their land. They will not be disturbed again; the wicked nations won’t conquer them as they did before

10.verse: when the judges ruled them. I will subdue all of your enemies. And I now declare that I will cause your descendants to be kings of Israel just as you are.

11.verse: “‘When your time here on earth is over and you die, I will place one of your sons upon your throne; and I will make his kingdom strong.

12.verse: He is the one who shall build me a temple, and I will establish his royal line of descent forever.

13.verse: I will be his father, and he shall be my son; I will never remove my mercy and love from him as I did from Saul.

14.verse: I will place him over my people and over the kingdom of Israel forever—and his descendants will always be kings.’”

15.verse: So Nathan told King David everything the Lord had said.

16.verse: Then King David went in and sat before the Lord and said, “Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my family that you have given me all this?

17.verse: For all the great things you have already done for me are nothing in comparison to what you have promised to do in the future! For now, O Lord God, you are speaking of future generations of my children being kings too! You speak as though I were someone very great.

18.verse: What else can I say? You know that I am but a dog, yet you have decided to honor me!

19.verse: O Lord, you have given me these wonderful promises just because you want to be kind to me, because of your own great heart.

20.verse: O Lord, there is no one like you—there is no other God. In fact, we have never even heard of another god like you!

21.verse: “And what other nation in all the earth is like Israel? You have made a unique nation and have redeemed it from Egypt so that the people could be your people. And you made a great name for yourself when you did glorious miracles in driving out the nations from before your people.

22.verse: You have declared that your people Israel belong to you forever, and you have become their God.

23.verse: “And now I accept your promise, Lord, that I and my children will always rule this nation.

24.verse: And may this bring eternal honor to your name as everyone realizes that you always do what you say. They will exclaim, ‘The Lord of heaven is indeed the God of Israel!’ And Israel shall always be ruled by my children and their posterity!

25.verse: Now I have the courage to pray to you, for you have revealed this to me.

26.verse: God himself has promised this good thing to me!

27.verse: May this blessing rest upon my children forever, for when you grant a blessing, Lord, it is an eternal blessing!”

1.verse: David finally subdued the Philistines and conquered Gath and its surrounding towns.

2.verse: He also conquered Moab and required its people to send him a large sum of money every year.

3.verse: He conquered the dominion of King Hadadezer of Zobah (as far as Hamath) at the time Hadadezer went to tighten his grip along the Euphrates River.

4.verse: David captured a thousand of his chariots, seven thousand cavalry, and twenty thousand troops. He crippled all the chariot teams except a hundred that he kept for his own use.

5.verse: When the Syrians arrived from Damascus to help King Hadadezer, David killed twenty-two thousand of them;

6.verse: then he placed a garrison of his troops in Damascus, the Syrian capital. So the Syrians, too, were forced to send him large amounts of money every year. And the Lord gave David victory everywhere he went.

7.verse: He brought the gold shields of King Hadadezer’s officers to Jerusalem,

8.verse: as well as a great amount of bronze from Hadadezer’s cities of Tibhath and Cun. (King Solomon later melted the bronze and used it for the Temple. He molded it into the bronze tank, the pillars, and the instruments used in offering sacrifices on the altar.)

9.verse: When King Tou of Hamath learned that King David had destroyed Hadadezer’s army,

10.verse: he sent his son Hadoram to greet and congratulate King David on his success and to present him with many gifts of gold, silver, and bronze, seeking an alliance. For Hadadezer and Tou had been enemies and there had been many wars between them.

11.verse: King David dedicated these gifts to the Lord, as he did the silver and gold he took from the nations of Edom, Moab, Ammon, Amalek, and the Philistines.

12.verse: Abishai (son of Zeruiah) then destroyed eighteen thousand Edomites in Salt Valley.

13.verse: He put garrisons in Edom and forced the Edomites to pay large sums of money annually to David. This is just another example of how the Lord gave David victory after victory.

14.verse: David reigned over all of Israel and was a just ruler.

15.verse: Joab (son of Zeruiah) was commander-in-chief of the army; Jehoshaphat (son of Ahilud) was the historian;

16.verse: Zadok (son of Ahitub) and Ahimelech (son of Abiathar) were the head priests; Shavsha was the king’s special assistant;

17.verse: Benaiah (son of Jehoiada) was in charge of the king’s bodyguard—the Cherethites and Pelethites—and David’s sons were his chief aides.

1.verse: When King Nahash of Ammon died, his son Hanun became the new king.

2.verse: Then David declared, “I am going to show friendship to Hanun because of all the kind things his father did for me.” So David sent a message of sympathy to Hanun for the death of his father. But when David’s ambassadors arrived, King Hanun’s counselors warned him, “Don’t fool yourself that David has sent these men to honor your father! They are here to spy out the land so that they can come in and conquer it!”

3.verse: Then David declared, “I am going to show friendship to Hanun because of all the kind things his father did for me.” So David sent a message of sympathy to Hanun for the death of his father. But when David’s ambassadors arrived, King Hanun’s counselors warned him, “Don’t fool yourself that David has sent these men to honor your father! They are here to spy out the land so that they can come in and conquer it!”

4.verse: So King Hanun insulted King David’s ambassadors by shaving their beards and cutting their robes off at the middle to expose their buttocks; then he sent them back to David in shame.

5.verse: When David heard what had happened, he sent a message to his embarrassed emissaries, telling them to stay at Jericho until their beards had grown out again.

6.verse: When King Hanun realized his mistake he sent $2,000,000 to enlist mercenary troops, chariots, and cavalry from Mesopotamia, Aram-maacah, and Zobah.

7.verse: He hired thirty-two thousand chariots, as well as the support of the king of Maacah and his entire army. These forces camped at Medeba where they were joined by the troops King Hanun had recruited from his cities.

8.verse: When David learned of this, he sent Joab and the mightiest warriors of Israel.

9.verse: The army of Ammon went out to meet them and began the battle at the gates of the city of Medeba. Meanwhile, the mercenary forces were out in the field.

10.verse: When Joab realized that the enemy forces were both in front and behind him, he divided his army and sent one group to engage the Syrians.

11.verse: The other group, under the command of his brother Abishai, moved against the Ammonites.

12.verse: “If the Syrians are too strong for me, come and help me,” Joab told his brother; “and if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I’ll come and help you.

13.verse: Be courageous and let us act like men to save our people and the cities of our God. And may the Lord do what is best.”

14.verse: So Joab and his troops attacked the Syrians, and the Syrians turned and fled.

15.verse: When the Ammonites, under attack by Abishai’s troops, saw that the Syrians were retreating, they fled into the city. Then Joab returned to Jerusalem.

16.verse: After their defeat, the Syrians summoned additional troops from east of the Euphrates River, led personally by Shophach, King Hadadezer’s commander-in-chief.

17.verse: When this news reached David, he mobilized all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and engaged the enemy troops in battle. But the Syrians again fled from David, and he killed seven thousand charioteers and forty thousand of their troops. He also killed Shophach, the commander-in-chief of the Syrian army.

18.verse: When this news reached David, he mobilized all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and engaged the enemy troops in battle. But the Syrians again fled from David, and he killed seven thousand charioteers and forty thousand of their troops. He also killed Shophach, the commander-in-chief of the Syrian army.

19.verse: Then King Hadadezer’s troops surrendered to King David and became his subjects. And never again did the Syrians aid the Ammonites in their battles.

1.verse: The following spring (spring was the season when wars usually began) Joab led the Israeli army in successful attacks against the cities and villages of the people of Ammon. After destroying them, he laid siege to Rabbah and conquered it. Meanwhile, David had stayed in Jerusalem.

2.verse: When David arrived on the scene, he removed the crown from the head of King Milcom of Rabbah and placed it upon his own head. It was made of gold inlaid with gems and weighed seventy-five pounds! David also took great amounts of plunder from the city.

3.verse: He drove the people from the city and set them to work with saws, iron picks, and axes, as was his custom with all the conquered Ammonite peoples. Then David and all his army returned to Jerusalem.

4.verse: The next war was against the Philistines again, at Gezer. But Sibbecai, a man from Hushath, killed one of the sons of the giant, Sippai, and so the Philistines surrendered.

5.verse: During another war with the Philistines, Elhanan (the son of Jair) killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath the giant; the handle of his spear was like a weaver’s beam!

6.verse: During another battle, at Gath, a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot (his father was also a giant) defied and taunted Israel; but he was killed by David’s nephew Jonathan, the son of David’s brother Shimea.

7.verse: During another battle, at Gath, a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot (his father was also a giant) defied and taunted Israel; but he was killed by David’s nephew Jonathan, the son of David’s brother Shimea.

8.verse: These giants were descendants of the giants of Gath, and they were killed by David and his soldiers.

1.verse: Then Satan brought disaster upon Israel, for he made David decide to take a census.

2.verse: “Take a complete census throughout the land and bring me the totals,” he told Joab and the other leaders.

3.verse: But Joab objected. “If the Lord were to multiply his people a hundred times, would they not all be yours? So why are you asking us to do this? Why must you cause Israel to sin?”

4.verse: But the king won the argument, and Joab did as he was told; he traveled all through Israel and returned to Jerusalem.

5.verse: The total population figure which he gave came to 1,100,000 men of military age in Israel and 470,000 in Judah.

6.verse: But he didn’t include the tribes of Levi and Benjamin in his figures because he was so distressed at what the king had made him do.

7.verse: And God, too, was displeased with the census and punished Israel for it.

8.verse: But David said to God, “I am the one who has sinned. Please forgive me, for I realize now how wrong I was to do this.”

9.verse: Then the Lord said to Gad, David’s personal prophet,

10.verse: “Go and tell David, ‘The Lord has offered you three choices. Which will you choose?

11.verse: “Go and tell David, ‘The Lord has offered you three choices. Which will you choose?

12.verse: You may have three years of famine, or three months of destruction by the enemies of Israel, or three days of deadly plague as the Angel of the Lord brings destruction to the land. Think it over and let me know what answer to return to the one who sent me.’”

13.verse: “This is a terrible decision to make,” David replied, “but let me fall into the hands of the Lord rather than into the power of men, for God’s mercies are very great.”

14.verse: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel and 70,000 men died as a result.

15.verse: During the plague God sent an Angel to destroy Jerusalem; but then he felt such compassion that he changed his mind and commanded the destroying Angel, “Stop! It is enough!” (The Angel of the Lord was standing at the time by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.)

16.verse: When David saw the Angel of the Lord standing between heaven and earth with his sword drawn, pointing toward Jerusalem, he and the elders of Israel clothed themselves in sackcloth and fell to the ground before the Lord.

17.verse: And David said to God, “I am the one who sinned by ordering the census. But what have these sheep done? O Lord my God, destroy me and my family, but do not destroy your people.”

18.verse: Then the Angel of the Lord told Gad to instruct David to build an altar to the Lord at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.

19.verse: So David went to see Ornan, who was threshing wheat at the time. Ornan saw the Angel as he turned, and his four sons ran and hid.

20.verse: So David went to see Ornan, who was threshing wheat at the time. Ornan saw the Angel as he turned, and his four sons ran and hid.

21.verse: Then Ornan saw the king approaching. So he left the threshing floor and bowed to the ground before King David.

22.verse: David said to Ornan, “Let me buy this threshing floor from you at its full price; then I will build an altar to the Lord and the plague will stop.”

23.verse: “Take it, my lord, and use it as you wish,” Ornan said to David. “Take the oxen, too, for burnt offerings; use the threshing instruments for wood for the fire and use the wheat for the grain offering. I give it all to you.”

24.verse: “No,” the king replied, “I will buy it for the full price; I cannot take what is yours and give it to the Lord. I will not offer a burnt offering that has cost me nothing!”

25.verse: So David paid Ornan $4,300 in gold

26.verse: and built an altar to the Lord there, and sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings upon it; and he called out to the Lord, who answered by sending down fire from heaven to burn up the offering on the altar.

27.verse: Then the Lord commanded the Angel to put back his sword into its sheath;

28.verse: and when David saw that the Lord had answered his plea, he sacrificed to him again.

29.verse: The Tabernacle and altar made by Moses in the wilderness were on the hill of Gibeon,

30.verse: but David didn’t have time to go there to plead before the Lord, for he was terrified by the drawn sword of the Angel of Jehovah.

1.verse: Then David said, “Right here at Ornan’s threshing floor is the place where I’ll build the Temple of the Lord and construct the altar for Israel’s burnt offering!”

2.verse: David now drafted all the resident aliens in Israel to prepare blocks of squared stone for the Temple.

3.verse: They also manufactured iron into the great quantity of nails needed for the doors in the gates and for the clamps; and they smelted so much bronze that it was too much to weigh.

4.verse: The men of Tyre and Sidon brought great rafts of cedar logs to David.

5.verse: “Solomon my son is young and tender,” David said, “and the Temple of the Lord must be a marvelous structure, famous and glorious throughout the world; so I will begin the preparations for it now.” So David collected the construction materials before his death.

6.verse: He now commanded his son Solomon to build a Temple for the Lord God of Israel.

7.verse: “I wanted to build it myself,” David told him,

8.verse: “but the Lord said not to do it. ‘You have killed too many men in great wars,’ he told me. ‘You have reddened the ground before me with blood: so you are not to build my Temple.

9.verse: But I will give you a son,’ he told me, ‘who will be a man of peace, for I will give him peace with his enemies in the surrounding lands. His name shall be Solomon (meaning “Peaceful”), and I will give peace and quietness to Israel during his reign.

10.verse: He shall build my Temple, and he shall be as my own son and I will be his father; and I will cause his sons and his descendants to reign over every generation of Israel.’

11.verse: “So now, my son, may the Lord be with you and prosper you as you do what he told you to do and build the Temple of the Lord.

12.verse: And may the Lord give you the good judgment to follow all his laws when he makes you king of Israel.

13.verse: For if you carefully obey the rules and regulations that he gave to Israel through Moses, you will prosper. Be strong and courageous, fearless and enthusiastic!

14.verse: “By hard work I have collected several billion dollars worth of gold bullion, millions in silver, and so much iron and bronze that I haven’t even weighed it; I have also gathered timber and stone for the walls. This is at least a beginning, something with which to start.

15.verse: And you have many skilled stonemasons and carpenters and craftsmen of every kind.

16.verse: They are expert gold and silver smiths and bronze and iron workers. So get to work, and may the Lord be with you!”

17.verse: Then David ordered all the leaders of Israel to assist his son in this project.

18.verse: “The Lord your God is with you,” he declared. “He has given you peace with the surrounding nations, for I have conquered them in the name of the Lord and for his people.

19.verse: Now try with every fiber of your being to obey the Lord your God, and you will soon be bringing the Ark and the other holy articles of worship into the Temple of the Lord!”

1.verse: By this time David was an old, old man, so he stepped down from the throne and appointed his son Solomon as the new king of Israel.

2.verse: He summoned all the political and religious leaders of Israel for the coronation ceremony.

3.verse: At this time a census was taken of the men of the tribe of Levi who were thirty years or older. The total came to 38,000.

4.verse: “Twenty-four thousand of them will supervise the work at the Temple,” David instructed, “6,000 are to be bailiffs and judges, 4,000 will be Temple guards, and 4,000 will praise the Lord with the musical instruments I have made.”

5.verse: “Twenty-four thousand of them will supervise the work at the Temple,” David instructed, “6,000 are to be bailiffs and judges, 4,000 will be Temple guards, and 4,000 will praise the Lord with the musical instruments I have made.”

6.verse: Then David divided them into three main divisions named after the sons of Levi—the Gershom division, the Kohath division, and the Merari division.

7.verse: Subdivisions of the Gershom corps were named after his sons Ladan and Shimei.

8.verse: These subdivisions were still further divided into six groups named after the sons of Ladan: Jehiel the leader, Zetham, Joel; and the sons of Shimei—Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran.

9.verse: These subdivisions were still further divided into six groups named after the sons of Ladan: Jehiel the leader, Zetham, Joel; and the sons of Shimei—Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran.

10.verse: The subclans of Shimei were named after his four sons: Jahath was greatest, Zizah was next, and Jeush and Beriah were combined into a single subclan because neither had many sons.

11.verse: The subclans of Shimei were named after his four sons: Jahath was greatest, Zizah was next, and Jeush and Beriah were combined into a single subclan because neither had many sons.

12.verse: The division of Kohath was subdivided into four groups named after his sons Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

13.verse: Amram was the ancestor of Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his sons were set apart for the holy service of sacrificing the people’s offerings to the Lord. He served the Lord constantly and pronounced blessings in his name at all times.

14.verse: As for Moses, the man of God, his sons, Gershom and Eliezer, were included with the tribe of Levi.

15.verse: As for Moses, the man of God, his sons, Gershom and Eliezer, were included with the tribe of Levi.

16.verse: Gershom’s sons were led by Shebuel,

17.verse: and Eliezer’s only son, Rehabiah, was the leader of his clan, for he had many children.

18.verse: The sons of Izhar were led by Shelomith.

19.verse: The sons of Hebron were led by Jeriah. Amariah was second in command, Jahaziel was third, and Jekameam was fourth.

20.verse: The sons of Uzziel were led by Micah, and Isshiah was the second in command.

21.verse: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. The sons of Mahli were Eleazar and Kish.

22.verse: Eleazar died without any sons, and his daughters were married to their cousins, the sons of Kish.

23.verse: Mushi’s sons were Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth.

24.verse: In the census, all the men of Levi who were twenty years old or older were classified under the names of these clans and subclans; and they were all assigned to the ministry at the Temple.

25.verse: For David said, “The Lord God of Israel has given us peace, and he will always live in Jerusalem.

26.verse: Now the Levites will no longer need to carry the Tabernacle and its instruments from place to place.”

27.verse: (This census of the tribe of Levi was one of the last things David did before his death.)

28.verse: The work of the Levites was to assist the priests—the descendants of Aaron—in the sacrifices at the Temple; they also did the custodial work and helped perform the ceremonies of purification.

29.verse: They provided the Bread of the Presence, the flour for the grain offerings, and the wafers made without yeast (either fried or mixed with olive oil); they also checked all the weights and measures.

30.verse: Each morning and evening they stood before the Lord to sing thanks and praise to him.

31.verse: They assisted in the special sacrifices of burnt offerings, the Sabbath sacrifices, the new moon celebrations, and at all the festivals. There were always as many Levites present as were required for the occasion.

32.verse: And they took care of the Tabernacle and the Temple and assisted the priests in whatever way they were needed.

1.verse: The priests (the descendants of Aaron) were placed into two divisions named after Aaron’s sons, Eleazar and Ithamar. Nadab and Abihu were also sons of Aaron, but they died before their father did and had no children; so only Eleazar and Ithamar were left to carry on.

2.verse: The priests (the descendants of Aaron) were placed into two divisions named after Aaron’s sons, Eleazar and Ithamar. Nadab and Abihu were also sons of Aaron, but they died before their father did and had no children; so only Eleazar and Ithamar were left to carry on.

3.verse: David consulted with Zadok, who represented the Eleazar clan, and with Ahimelech, who represented the Ithamar clan; then he divided Aaron’s descendants into many groups to serve at various times.

4.verse: Eleazar’s descendants were divided into sixteen groups and Ithamar’s into eight (for there was more leadership ability among the descendants of Eleazar).

5.verse: All tasks were assigned to the various groups by coin-toss so that there would be no preference, for there were many famous men and high officials of the Temple in each division.

6.verse: Shemaiah, a Levite and the son of Nethanel, acted as recording secretary and wrote down the names and assignments in the presence of the king and of these leaders: Zadok the priest, Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and the heads of the priests and Levites. Two groups from the division of Eleazar and one from the division of Ithamar were assigned to each task.

7.verse: The work was assigned (by coin-toss) in this order: First, the group led by Jehoiarib; Second, the group led by Jedaiah; Third, the group led by Harim; Fourth, the group led by Seorim; Fifth, the group led by Malchijah; Sixth, the group led by Mijamin; Seventh, the group led by Hakkoz; Eighth, the group led by Ahijah; Ninth, the group led by Jeshua; Tenth, the group led by Shecaniah; Eleventh, the group led by Eliashib; Twelfth, the group led by Jakim; Thirteenth, the group led by Huppah; Fourteenth, the group led by Jeshebeab; Fifteenth, the group led by Bilgah; Sixteenth, the group led by Immer; Seventeenth, the group led by Hezir; Eighteenth, the group led by Happizzez; Nineteenth, the group led by Pethahiah; Twentieth, the group led by Jehezkel; Twenty-first, the group led by Jachin; Twenty-second, the group led by Gamul; Twenty-third, the group led by Delaiah; Twenty-fourth, the group led by Maaziah.

19.verse: Each group carried out the Temple duties as originally assigned by God through their ancestor Aaron.

20.verse: These were the other descendants of Levi: Amram; his descendant Shubael; and Shubael’s descendant Jehdeiah;

21.verse: the Rehabiah group, led by his oldest son Isshiah;

22.verse: the Izhar group, consisting of Shelamoth and his descendant Jahath.

23.verse: The Hebron group: Jeriah, Hebron’s oldest son; Amariah, his second son; Jahaziel, his third son; Jekameam, his fourth son.

24.verse: The Uzziel group was led by his son Micah and his grandsons Shamir and Isshiah, and by Isshiah’s son Zechariah.

25.verse: The Uzziel group was led by his son Micah and his grandsons Shamir and Isshiah, and by Isshiah’s son Zechariah.

26.verse: The Merari group was led by his sons: Mahli and Mushi. (Jaaziah’s group, led by his son Beno, included his brothers Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.)

27.verse: The Merari group was led by his sons: Mahli and Mushi. (Jaaziah’s group, led by his son Beno, included his brothers Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.)

28.verse: Mahli’s descendants were Eleazar, who had no sons,

29.verse: and Kish, among whose sons was Jerahmeel.

30.verse: The sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the descendants of Levi in their various clans.

31.verse: Like the descendants of Aaron, they were assigned to their duties by coin-toss without distinction as to age or rank. It was done in the presence of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the leaders of the priests and the Levites.

1.verse: David and the officials of the Tabernacle then appointed men to prophesy to the accompaniment of zithers, harps, and cymbals. These men were from the groups of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun. Here is a list of their names and their work:

2.verse: Under the leadership of Asaph, the king’s private prophet, were his sons Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asharelah.

3.verse: Under Jeduthun, who led in giving thanks and praising the Lord (while accompanied by the zither), were his six sons: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah.

4.verse: Under the direction of Heman, the king’s private chaplain, were his sons: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Geddalti, Romamti-ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth. (For God had honored him with fourteen sons and three daughters.)

5.verse: Under the direction of Heman, the king’s private chaplain, were his sons: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Geddalti, Romamti-ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth. (For God had honored him with fourteen sons and three daughters.)

6.verse: Their music ministry included the playing of cymbals, harps, and zithers; all were under the direction of their father as they performed this ministry in the Tabernacle. Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman reported directly to the king. They and their families were all trained in singing praises to the Lord; each one—288 of them in all—was a master musician.

7.verse: Their music ministry included the playing of cymbals, harps, and zithers; all were under the direction of their father as they performed this ministry in the Tabernacle. Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman reported directly to the king. They and their families were all trained in singing praises to the Lord; each one—288 of them in all—was a master musician.

8.verse: The singers were appointed to their particular term of service by coin-toss, without regard to age or reputation.

1.verse: The Temple guards were from the Asaph division of the Korah clan. The captain of the guard was Meshelemiah, the son of Kore.

2.verse: His sergeants were his sons: Zechariah (the oldest), Jediael (the second), Zebadiah (the third), Jathniel (the fourth), Elam (the fifth), Jehohanan (the sixth), Eliehoenai (the seventh).

3.verse: His sergeants were his sons: Zechariah (the oldest), Jediael (the second), Zebadiah (the third), Jathniel (the fourth), Elam (the fifth), Jehohanan (the sixth), Eliehoenai (the seventh).

4.verse: The sons of Obed-edom were also appointed as Temple guards: Shemaiah (the oldest), Jehozabad (the second), Joah (the third), Sacar (the fourth), Nethanel (the fifth), Ammiel (the sixth), Issachar (the seventh), Peullethai (the eighth). What a blessing God gave him with all those sons!

5.verse: The sons of Obed-edom were also appointed as Temple guards: Shemaiah (the oldest), Jehozabad (the second), Joah (the third), Sacar (the fourth), Nethanel (the fifth), Ammiel (the sixth), Issachar (the seventh), Peullethai (the eighth). What a blessing God gave him with all those sons!

6.verse: Shemaiah’s sons were all outstanding men and had positions of great authority in their clan. Their names were: Othni, Rephael, Obed, Elzabad. Their brave brothers, Elihu and Semachiah, were also very able men.

7.verse: Shemaiah’s sons were all outstanding men and had positions of great authority in their clan. Their names were: Othni, Rephael, Obed, Elzabad. Their brave brothers, Elihu and Semachiah, were also very able men.

8.verse: All of these sons and grandsons of Obed-edom—all sixty-two of them—were outstanding men who were particularly well qualified for their work.

9.verse: Meshelemiah’s eighteen sons and brothers, too, were real leaders.

10.verse: Hosah, one of the Merari group, appointed Shimri as the leader among his sons, though he was not the oldest.

11.verse: The names of some of his other sons were: Hilkiah, the second; Tebaliah, the third; Zechariah, the fourth. Hosah’s sons and brothers numbered thirteen in all.

12.verse: The divisions of the Temple guards were named after the leaders. Like the other Levites, they were responsible to minister at the Temple.

13.verse: They were assigned guard duty at the various gates without regard to the reputation of their families, for it was all done by coin-toss.

14.verse: The responsibility of the east gate went to Shelemiah and his group; of the north gate to his son Zechariah, a man of unusual wisdom; of the south gate to Obed-edom and his group (his sons were given charge of the storehouses);

15.verse: The responsibility of the east gate went to Shelemiah and his group; of the north gate to his son Zechariah, a man of unusual wisdom; of the south gate to Obed-edom and his group (his sons were given charge of the storehouses);

16.verse: of the west gate and the Shallecheth Gate on the upper road, to Shuppim and Hosah.

17.verse: Six guards were assigned daily to the east gate, four to the north gate, four to the south gate, and two to each of the storehouses.

18.verse: Six guards were assigned each day to the west gate, four to the upper road, and two to the nearby areas.

19.verse: The Temple guards were chosen from the clans of Korah and Merari.

20.verse: Other Levites, led by Ahijah, were given the care of the gifts brought to the Lord and placed in the Temple treasury. These men of the Ladan subclan from the clan of Gershom included Zetham and Joel, the sons of Jehieli.

21.verse: Other Levites, led by Ahijah, were given the care of the gifts brought to the Lord and placed in the Temple treasury. These men of the Ladan subclan from the clan of Gershom included Zetham and Joel, the sons of Jehieli.

22.verse: Other Levites, led by Ahijah, were given the care of the gifts brought to the Lord and placed in the Temple treasury. These men of the Ladan subclan from the clan of Gershom included Zetham and Joel, the sons of Jehieli.

23.verse: Shebuel, son of Gershom and grandson of Moses, was the chief officer of the treasury. He was in charge of the divisions named after Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

24.verse: Shebuel, son of Gershom and grandson of Moses, was the chief officer of the treasury. He was in charge of the divisions named after Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

25.verse: The line of descendants from Eliezer went through Rehabiah, Jeshaiah, Joram, Zichri, and Shelomoth.

26.verse: Shelomoth and his brothers were appointed to care for the gifts given to the Lord by King David and the other leaders of the nation such as the officers and generals of the army.

27.verse: For these men dedicated their war loot to support the operating expenses of the Temple.

28.verse: Shelomoth and his brothers were also responsible for the care of the items dedicated to the Lord by Samuel the prophet, Saul the son of Kish, Abner the son of Ner, Joab the son of Zeruiah, and anyone else of distinction who brought gifts to the Lord.

29.verse: Chenaniah and his sons (from the subclan of Izhar) were appointed public administrators and judges.

30.verse: Hashabiah and 1,700 of his clansmen from Hebron, all outstanding men, were placed in charge of the territory of Israel west of the Jordan River; they were responsible for the religious affairs and public administration of that area.

31.verse: Twenty-seven hundred outstanding men of the clan of the Hebronites, under the supervision of Jerijah, were appointed to control the religious and public affairs of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. These men, all of whom had excellent qualifications, were appointed on the basis of their ancestry and ability at Jazer in Gilead in the fortieth year of King David’s reign.

32.verse: Twenty-seven hundred outstanding men of the clan of the Hebronites, under the supervision of Jerijah, were appointed to control the religious and public affairs of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. These men, all of whom had excellent qualifications, were appointed on the basis of their ancestry and ability at Jazer in Gilead in the fortieth year of King David’s reign.

1.verse: The Israeli army was divided into twelve regiments, each with 24,000 troops, including officers and administrative staff. These units were called up for active duty one month each year. Here is the list of the units and their regimental commanders:

2.verse: The commander of the First Division was Jashobeam. He had charge of 24,000 troops who were on duty the first month of each year.

3.verse: The commander of the First Division was Jashobeam. He had charge of 24,000 troops who were on duty the first month of each year.

4.verse: The commander of the Second Division was Dodai (a descendant of Ahohi). He had charge of 24,000 troops who were on duty the second month of each year. Mikloth was his executive officer.

5.verse: The commander of the Third Division was Benaiah. His 24,000 men were on duty the third month of each year. (He was the son of Jehoiada the High Priest and was the chief of The Thirty, a group including the mightiest of David’s men.) His son Ammizabad succeeded him as division commander.

6.verse: The commander of the Third Division was Benaiah. His 24,000 men were on duty the third month of each year. (He was the son of Jehoiada the High Priest and was the chief of The Thirty, a group including the mightiest of David’s men.) His son Ammizabad succeeded him as division commander.

7.verse: The commander of the Fourth Division was Asahel (the brother of Joab), who was later replaced by his son Zebadiah. He had 24,000 men on duty the fourth month of each year.

8.verse: The commander of the Fifth Division was Shamuth from Izrah, with 24,000 men on duty the fifth month of each year.

9.verse: The commander of the Sixth Division was Ira, the son of Ikkesh from Tekoa; he had 24,000 men on duty the sixth month of each year.

10.verse: The commander of the Seventh Division was Helez from Pelona in Ephraim, with 24,000 men on duty the seventh month of each year.

11.verse: The commander of the Eighth Division was Sibbecai of the Hushite subclan from Zerah, who had 24,000 men on duty the eighth month of each year.

12.verse: The commander of the Ninth Division was Abiezer (from Anathoth in the tribe of Benjamin), who commanded 24,000 troops during the ninth month of each year.

13.verse: The commander of the Tenth Division was Maharai from Netophah in Zerah, with 24,000 men on duty the tenth month of each year.

14.verse: The commander of the Eleventh Division was Benaiah from Pirathon in Ephraim, with 24,000 men on duty during the eleventh month of each year.

15.verse: The commander of the Twelfth Division was Heldai from Netophah in the area of Othniel, who commanded 24,000 men on duty during the twelfth month of each year.

16.verse: The top political officers of the tribes of Israel were as follows: Over Reuben, Eliezer (son of Zichri); Over Simeon, Shephatiah (son of Maacah); Over Levi, Hashabiah (son of Kemuel); Over the descendants of Aaron, Zadok; Over Judah, Elihu (a brother of King David); Over Issachar, Omri (son of Michael); Over Zebulun, Ishmaiah (son of Obadiah); Over Naphtali, Jeremoth (son of Azriel); Over Ephraim, Hoshea (son of Azaziah); Over the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joel (son of Pedaiah); Over the other half of Manasseh, in Gilead, Iddo (son of Zechariah); Over Benjamin, Jaasiel (son of Abner); Over Dan, Azarel (son of Jeroham).

17.verse: The top political officers of the tribes of Israel were as follows: Over Reuben, Eliezer (son of Zichri); Over Simeon, Shephatiah (son of Maacah); Over Levi, Hashabiah (son of Kemuel); Over the descendants of Aaron, Zadok; Over Judah, Elihu (a brother of King David); Over Issachar, Omri (son of Michael); Over Zebulun, Ishmaiah (son of Obadiah); Over Naphtali, Jeremoth (son of Azriel); Over Ephraim, Hoshea (son of Azaziah); Over the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joel (son of Pedaiah); Over the other half of Manasseh, in Gilead, Iddo (son of Zechariah); Over Benjamin, Jaasiel (son of Abner); Over Dan, Azarel (son of Jeroham).

22.verse: The top political officers of the tribes of Israel were as follows: Over Reuben, Eliezer (son of Zichri); Over Simeon, Shephatiah (son of Maacah); Over Levi, Hashabiah (son of Kemuel); Over the descendants of Aaron, Zadok; Over Judah, Elihu (a brother of King David); Over Issachar, Omri (son of Michael); Over Zebulun, Ishmaiah (son of Obadiah); Over Naphtali, Jeremoth (son of Azriel); Over Ephraim, Hoshea (son of Azaziah); Over the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joel (son of Pedaiah); Over the other half of Manasseh, in Gilead, Iddo (son of Zechariah); Over Benjamin, Jaasiel (son of Abner); Over Dan, Azarel (son of Jeroham).

23.verse: When David took his census, he didn’t include the twenty-year-olds or those younger, for the Lord had promised a population explosion for his people.

24.verse: Joab began the census, but he never finished it, for the anger of God broke out upon Israel; the final total was never put into the annals of King David.

25.verse: Azmaveth (son of Adiel) was the chief financial officer in charge of the palace treasuries, and Jonathan (son of Uzziah) was chief of the regional treasuries throughout the cities, villages, and fortresses of Israel.

26.verse: Ezri (son of Chelub) was manager of the laborers on the king’s estates.

27.verse: And Shimei from Ramath had the oversight of the king’s vineyards; and Zabdi from Shiphma was responsible for his wine production and storage.

28.verse: Baal-hanan from Gedera was responsible for the king’s olive yards and sycamore trees in the lowlands bordering Philistine territory, while Joash had charge of the supplies of olive oil.

29.verse: Shitrai from Sharon was in charge of the cattle on the plains of Sharon, and Shaphat (son of Adlai) had charge of those in the valleys.

30.verse: Obil, from the territory of Ishmael, had charge of the camels, and Jehdeiah from Meronoth had charge of the donkeys.

31.verse: The sheep were under the care of Jaziz the Hagrite. These men were King David’s overseers.

32.verse: The attendant to the king’s sons was Jonathan, David’s uncle, a wise counselor and an educated man. Jehiel (the son of Hachmoni) was their tutor.

33.verse: Ahithophel was the king’s official counselor, and Hushai the Archite was his personal advisor.

34.verse: Ahithophel was assisted by Jehoiada (the son of Benaiah) and by Abiathar. Joab was commander-in-chief of the Israeli army.

1.verse: David now summoned all of his officials to Jerusalem—the political leaders, the commanders of the twelve army divisions, the other army officers, those in charge of his property and livestock, and all the other men of authority in his kingdom.

2.verse: He rose and stood before them and addressed them as follows: “My brothers and my people! It was my desire to build a temple in which the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord could rest—a place for our God to live in. I have now collected everything that is necessary for the building,

3.verse: but God has told me, ‘You are not to build my temple, for you are a warrior and have shed much blood.’

4.verse: “Nevertheless, the Lord God of Israel has chosen me from among all my father’s family to begin a dynasty that will rule Israel forever; he has chosen the tribe of Judah, and from among the families of Judah, my father’s family; and from among his sons, the Lord took pleasure in me and has made me king over all Israel.

5.verse: And from among my sons—the Lord has given me many children—he has chosen Solomon to succeed me on the throne of his kingdom of Israel.

6.verse: He has told me, ‘Your son Solomon shall build my Temple; for I have chosen him as my son and I will be his father.

7.verse: And if he continues to obey my commandments and instructions as he has until now, I will make his kingdom last forever.’”

8.verse: Then David turned to Solomon and said: “Here before the leaders of Israel, the people of God, and in the sight of our God, I am instructing you to search out every commandment of the Lord so that you may continue to rule this good land and leave it to your children to rule forever.

9.verse: Solomon, my son, get to know the God of your fathers. Worship and serve him with a clean heart and a willing mind, for the Lord sees every heart and understands and knows every thought. If you seek him, you will find him; but if you forsake him, he will permanently throw you aside.

10.verse: So be very careful, for the Lord has chosen you to build his holy Temple. Be strong and do as he commands.”

11.verse: Then David gave Solomon the blueprint of the Temple and its surroundings—the treasuries, the upstairs rooms, the inside rooms, and the sanctuary for the place of mercy.

12.verse: He also gave Solomon his plans for the outer court, the outside rooms, the Temple storage areas, and the treasuries for the gifts dedicated by famous persons. For the Holy Spirit had given David all these plans.

13.verse: The king also passed on to Solomon the instructions concerning the work of the various groups of priests and Levites; and he gave specifications for each item in the Temple which was to be used for worship and sacrifice.

14.verse: David weighed out enough gold and silver to make these various items,

15.verse: as well as the specific amount of gold needed for the lampstands and lamps. He also weighed out enough silver for the silver candlesticks and lamps, each according to its use.

16.verse: He weighed out the gold for the table on which the Bread of the Presence would be placed and for the other gold tables, and he weighed the silver for the silver tables.

17.verse: Then he weighed out the gold for the solid gold hooks used in handling the sacrificial meat and for the basins, cups, and bowls of gold and silver.

18.verse: Finally, he weighed out the refined gold for the altar of incense and for the gold Guardian Angels whose wings were stretched over the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord.

19.verse: “Every part of this blueprint,” David told Solomon, “was given to me in writing from the hand of the Lord.”

20.verse: Then he continued, “Be strong and courageous and get to work. Don’t be frightened by the size of the task, for the Lord my God is with you; he will not forsake you. He will see to it that everything is finished correctly.

21.verse: And these various groups of priests and Levites will serve in the Temple. Others with skills of every kind will volunteer, and the army and the entire nation are at your command.”

1.verse: Then King David turned to the entire assembly and said: “My son Solomon, whom God has chosen to be the next king of Israel, is still young and inexperienced, and the work ahead of him is enormous; for the temple he will build is not just another building—it is for the Lord God himself!

2.verse: Using every resource at my command, I have gathered as much as I could for building it—enough gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and great quantities of onyx, other precious stones, costly jewels, and marble.

3.verse: And now, because of my devotion to the Temple of God, I am giving all of my own private treasures to aid in the construction. This is in addition to the building materials I have already collected.

4.verse: These personal contributions consist of millions of dollars of gold from Ophir and huge amounts of silver to be used for overlaying the walls of the buildings. It will also be used for the articles made of gold and silver and for the artistic decorations. Now then, who will follow my example? Who will give himself and all that he has to the Lord?”

5.verse: These personal contributions consist of millions of dollars of gold from Ophir and huge amounts of silver to be used for overlaying the walls of the buildings. It will also be used for the articles made of gold and silver and for the artistic decorations. Now then, who will follow my example? Who will give himself and all that he has to the Lord?”

6.verse: Then the clan leaders, the heads of the tribes, the army officers, and the administrative officers of the king pledged huge sums of gold, silver, and foreign currency, also 675 tons of bronze and 3,750 tons of iron.

7.verse: Then the clan leaders, the heads of the tribes, the army officers, and the administrative officers of the king pledged huge sums of gold, silver, and foreign currency, also 675 tons of bronze and 3,750 tons of iron.

8.verse: They also contributed great amounts of jewelry, which were deposited at the Temple treasury with Jehiel (a descendant of Gershom).

9.verse: Everyone was excited and happy for this opportunity of service, and King David was moved with deep joy.

10.verse: While still in the presence of the whole assembly, David expressed his praises to the Lord: “O Lord God of our father Israel, praise your name for ever and ever!

11.verse: Yours is the mighty power and glory and victory and majesty. Everything in the heavens and earth is yours, O Lord, and this is your kingdom. We adore you as being in control of everything.

12.verse: Riches and honor come from you alone, and you are the ruler of all mankind; your hand controls power and might, and it is at your discretion that men are made great and given strength.

13.verse: O our God, we thank you and praise your glorious name,

14.verse: but who am I and who are my people that we should be permitted to give anything to you? Everything we have has come from you, and we only give you what is yours already!

15.verse: For we are here for but a moment, strangers in the land as our fathers were before us; our days on earth are like a shadow, gone so soon, without a trace.

16.verse: O Lord our God, all of this material that we have gathered to build a temple for your holy name comes from you! It all belongs to you!

17.verse: I know, my God, that you test men to see if they are good; for you enjoy good men. I have done all this with good motives, and I have watched your people offer their gifts willingly and joyously.

18.verse: “O Lord, God of our fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Israel! Make your people always want to obey you, and see to it that their love for you never changes.

19.verse: Give my son Solomon a good heart toward God, so that he will want to obey you in the smallest detail and will look forward eagerly to finishing the building of your Temple, for which I have made all of these preparations.”

20.verse: Then David said to all the people, “Give praise to the Lord your God!” And they did, bowing low before the Lord and the king.

21.verse: The next day they brought a thousand young bulls, a thousand rams, and a thousand lambs as burnt offerings to the Lord; they also offered drink offerings and many other sacrifices on behalf of all Israel.

22.verse: Then they feasted and drank before the Lord with great joy. And again they crowned King David’s son Solomon as their king. They anointed him before the Lord as their leader, and they anointed Zadok as their priest.

23.verse: So God appointed Solomon to take the throne of his father David; and he prospered greatly, and all Israel obeyed him.

24.verse: The national leaders, the army officers, and his brothers all pledged their allegiance to King Solomon.

25.verse: And the Lord gave him great popularity with all the people of Israel, and he amassed even greater wealth and honor than his father.

26.verse: David was king of the land of Israel for forty years; seven of them during his reign in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.

27.verse: David was king of the land of Israel for forty years; seven of them during his reign in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.

28.verse: He died at an old age, wealthy and honored; and his son Solomon reigned in his place.

29.verse: Detailed biographies of King David have been written in the history of Samuel the prophet, in the history written by Nathan the prophet, and in the history written by the prophet Gad.

30.verse: These accounts tell of his reign and of his might and all that happened to him and to Israel and to the kings of the nearby nations.
